title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: When we put them forward next March we will be an independent nation again.Even Philip Hammond will need to crack a smile.Because as we approach Brexit, the people of this country will want to hear details about the enormous benefits of our long, hard battle to finally wrest control from the EU.They will want to be told about lower taxes, cheaper goods and the biggest boost for business in our nation’s history.The Chancellor’s £billion spending proposals on social care and our roads in tomorrow’s budget are, of course, welcome.But they do not come near enough to the sort of good news we expect to hear on March .We would prefer Mr Hammond to tell us how he is going to put more money in people’s pockets.After all, what is the point of the Tories,they don’t stand for people keeping hold of more of their hard-earned cash We would also like the Chancellor to show his plans to kickstart Britain’s productivity, innovation and growth, across every corner of the country.Slashing business taxes will help private companies grow, whether big outfits or hard-working Sun on Sunday readers setting up small firms.We have the fourth-lowest home-ownership rate in the EU. If the Tories don’t address this, voters will punish them.Their long-term success depends on creating and sustaining a property-owning democracy.Once we are unshackled from Brussels, the whole world will open up for us.And we will have opportunity to properly prosper as an independent nation once again.Filling in our potholes is all well and good, but the Government must focus on laying the foundations to make sure Britain is on the road to a GREAT future.SOME good Brexit advice for the PM.Don’t be a pushover, walk in like you mean business and be prepared to wait for the best deal.But this guidance doesn’t come from the IMF, the BoE or even the IoD.It’s courtesy of a South London businessman: Mr Del Boy Trotter of Peckham.Theresa May could do worse than read his Sun column.Mais oui! title: meghan markle comforted a sobbing fan by doing something very sweet
story: The former actress was attending a ceremony to mark the th anniversary of the women’s suffrage in New Zealand at the National War Memorial.The Duchess of Sussex met one girl who promptly burst into tears when she met the former Suits actress.Meghan immediately tried to comfort the teenage girl by clasping her face as she continued to sob.The expectant mother was even seen rubbing her wrists in a bid to calm her down.Journalist Natalie Oliveri, who witnessed the moment, said: “Absolute hysteria here in Wellington including a sobbing fan who was comforted by the Duchess herself!“Meghan spent quite a while talking to the crying teen - one of the sweetest moments on the royal tour so far!”The Royal’s have been on a whirlwind  day tour of Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga.Tomorrow, they are due to visit Wellington Cafe to discuss mental health projects in the country, then head to Abel Tasman National Park.They will be greeted by a welcome ceremony on arrival, before joining the parks young ambassadors and local school children at a barbeque and for a tree planting.On the walk, Harry and Meghan will learn from rangers about the history of the forest and the environmental challenges of protecting the parks habitat.

title: gagging order reform sir philip green claims
story: Government sources said new rules will be unveiled before Christmas that will be explicit when a non-disclosure agreementdoes not apply or cant be enforced.Theresa May had already promised to crackdown on the use of NDAs to silence complaints of sexual harassment but she has ordered ministers to accelerate plans to tighten current regulations after the bombshell revelations over Sir Philips use of them to silence ex-staffers.At the weekend it was claimed he had paid staff members seven-figure sums to silence allegations of sexual harassment and bullying.The Government Equalities Office is conducting a consultation on how to overhaul current rules governing gagging orders.But insiders say that one of the decisions already made is the new rules will bar all future NDAs from banning whistle-blowing.One Whitehall insider working on the plans said: The starting point is that NDAs shouldnt be allowed to stop people from whistle-blowing and some employers are using them unethically so the consultation will look at improving the regulations around them.Maria Miller, chairman of the Commons Equalities committee, said the furore over the process of naming Sir Philip in Parliament must not overshadow the urgent need to reform the use of NDAs.She told Pienaar’s Politics on Radio  Live: “What Im more interested in is that it doesnt eclipse the importance of really getting change in a non-disclosure system, which is you know covering up serious allegations - and more importantly than that, is the legal system appears to be allowing people to do this.”It emerged that Labour staffers have been forced to sign controversial non-disclosure contracts that ban them from speaking out about members’ actions – even though Jeremy Corbyn has vowed to ban them.Dozens of former party staffers have been forced to sign agreements to stop them going public on the complaints against Labour party members, which include harassment, bullying and anti-Semitism, The Sunday Times reported.But after the “Sir” Philip Green scandal last week, it is clear to all that they are being grossly misused.NDAs were not created so that the rich and powerful could gag people who make serious accusations against them.In a free society, people must always be able to blow the whistle.Sources told the paper that the party boss was guilty of “hypocrisy” for campaigning to ban such NDAs clauses.One said: “A decent number of now former Labour staff are also subject to NDAs, which is stopping them speaking out on sexual harassment cases or anti-Semitism.”Back in June Mr Corbyn said that anything which prevented the disclosure of information about discrimination, harassment or victimisation would be outlawed under a future Labour government.“Labour will bring about a workplace rights revolution, so people are free to do their jobs, in the hospitality sector and beyond, without facing unacceptable behaviour and abuses of power from colleagues, clients or customers,” he said at the time.Labour’s John Mann said: “On Friday my closing remarks at the national child abuse enquiry recommended an immediate removal of all NDAs by local councils.“The same goes immediately for the Labour Party in all these cases.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hammond austerity spending budget
story: He will unveil a £billion a year package to provide crisis services for people suffering from mental health problems.The money – part of the £billion a year NHS cash injection already announced – will help put a dedicated mental health team in every AE and state school.More ambulances will also be equipped with mental health specialists who will be able to respond to people having violent breakdowns - relieving other public services like the police.The Chancellor will delight motorists with a £billion five-year spending spree on fixing Britain’s crumbling roads – as well as extending the £billion a year fuel duty freeze.He is also expected to announce up to £million extra spending on defence after intense lobbying by Tory MPs.Other spending pledges expected today include a £.billion to slash small retailers’ business rates bills by a third, nearly £billion extra for elderly social care, hundreds of millions to boost rural internet and £million to plant trees to boost property values and protect against flooding.And Mr Hammond could also bring forward a popular income tax cut by raising the personal allowance to £, and higher rate threshold to £, as early as next to echo the Prime Minister’s promise to end austerity – a pledge that formed the key plank of her Tory party conference speech last week.It is the latest sign of the tensions with Mrs May over her that the fruits of their hard work are now at last in sight.“What I will be doing is setting out a path of public spending that will take us from the spending review onwards, but the detailed allocation to dferent departments is something that is for next year.”Mr Hammond’s £billion a year extra for mental health services will be the first stage of the NHS’s long-term plan to achieve “parity of care” between physical and mental health.The extra cash will help pay for the provision of “comprehensive” mental health support in every major NHS AE department, ensuring anyone experiencing a mental health crisis can get rapid specialist help.Officials say it will be backed up with more mental health ambulances and the establishment of dedicated mental health teams in schools, linking them to other support services.Callers to NHS  will be directed to support services  hours a day and there will be greater access to services in the community, such as “crisis cafes” where people can get help without going to AE.The additional funding forms part of the extra £ billion-a-year by  for the NHS in England which Theresa May announced in June.But Labour’s shadow health minister Barbara Keeley expressed scepticism about the promise of extra funding.“If this announcement is simply money that’s already been promised, it will do little to relieve the severe pressures on mental health services that have built up because of this Tory Government’s relentless underfunding of the NHS,” he said.“People with mental health conditions cannot afford to wait five years for meaningful action from this Government: too many are already waiting many months to access the treatment.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit theresa may replaced poll
story: A survey by pollsters ORB found  per cent of Brits want a change of leader to takeover Brexit negotiations - compared to just  per cent who support Theresa May remaining in charge.It also finds a third of voters would be in favour of Britain walking out of talks with Brussels altogether and start preparing full-tilt for a no deal Brexit.But  per cent oppose pulling out of negotiations at this stage.Remarkably, support for a change in PM before Brexit won backing across all age groups.Half of those aged between - want to see a change - with just  per cent backing her to stay.The group most in favour of her staying were the oldest voters - those aged over .Men were more likely than women to want a change with  per cent of male voters backing someone  to take charge of Brexit negotiations compared to  per cent of women wanting Mrs May gone.The findings will embolden Brexiteers who are increasingly rallying around David Davis to be installed as an interim Prime Minister to negotiate a Canada-style exit from the EU.Others in the party still want Boris Johnson to take over.A senior Brexit source said the poll dispels the myth that only Mrs May can lead our exit talks.The source said: “The public are looking for much more leadership and a much tougher approach to the EU.“Their sense of frustration is very evident in the findings of this poll.“Across the whole demographic is a net positive in favour of somebody  leading the negotiations.“Sun readers will want a politician in charge who would take a much tougher, more robust approach to the negotiations.“Although people are broadly sympathetic to the Prime Minister because it’s a dficult situation, their patience is running out now and they want someone who is more able to stand up for the UK’s interests with the EU negotiators.”Men were also more likely to back Britain pulling out of negotiations than women.Some  per cent of men said the UK should leave the talks now - one point higher than the number of men who want us to stay in the room.But a third of women want us to carry on negotiating, compared to  per cent who want British negotiators to walk out.Older voters are more likely to want us to pull-out and start preparing for a no deal Brexit, with  per cent of over s backing this option.Tory MP David Jones said the findings showed widespread support among the public to dare to walk away from the negotiating table and start properly preparing for a no deal Brexit, which would see us trading with countries on World Trade Organisation tarfs.He said the results of the poll strengthens the argument for the PM to ditch her Chequers proposal and opt for a Canada-style trade deal with the EU.And he said the Government should drop all plans to comply with EU demands to agree a backstop to avoid theof the Irish border.Mr Jones told The Sun: “I think that it’s very obvious that a World Trade Organisation deal - which a no deal is referred to - would be highly desirable.“We would not be obliged to pay the £ billion-plus that the EU is demanding, we would be in a position to strike free trade deals around the world, which we would not be able to do under the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposals.“And I can well understand that people would want that freedom to trade with the rest of the world which we would not be able to do with Chequers.”He added: “An even better deal would be a Canada-style free trade agreement, which the EU has already offered us.“The only reason we can’t proceed with that is because of the Northern Ireland backstop which the government should be ruling out completely.“We don’t need a backstop - it’s something the EU has dreamt up and for which there is no real justication.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: terrifying moment circus lion pounces on four year old girl and sinks its teeth into her face scarring her for life
story: The beast pulled the girl into the ring and mauled in Russia.The girl named Ksenia survived the big cat attack but doctors say she will be scarred for le after sustaining serious face and chest injuries.She had been waving a small flag when the lioness rushed from its trainer despite being on a leash and sprang on the child.One account said the wild animal broke a flimsy safety net around the circus ring at Uspenskoye village in Krasnodar region.Valentina Pavlova said she was a member of a medical team which treated the girl at the Central Republican Hospital in Krasnodar.She said: “There is a bite on her face that goes from ear to chin.“An eyewitness said her mother had allowed the girl to get close to the safety net and to wave a banner.“The lioness reacted to this and with its paw pulled the child inside into the arena and sank its teeth into her head.“The circus team pulled the lioness away and brought the girl to the Central Republican Hospital.“She is now in stable condition, there is no danger to her le.”She is being treated in intensive care.Edgard Zapashny, director of Big Moscow state circus, said both the local circus and the girl’s mother were responsible.“I firmly believe that the blame lies completely with the owner and director of that travelling circus, the lioness’s trainer and on the adult who came with the child and let go of her while being in the front row.”Wild animals continue to be used for performances in Russian circuses.The attack is likely to lead to increased calls to ban the use of performing predators like lions and bears.

title: boy almost lost testicle twisted
story: The -year-old was taken to AE after suffering pain and swelling on the right side of his groin.He told doctors he felt a severe, dull, aching and unremitting pain that was causing him to feel nauseous.Three months earlier he had been treated for a right inguinal hernia - a condition that causes tissue, such as part of the intestine, to protrude through a weak spot in the abdominal wall.The hernia can cause a bulge and pain around the pubic bone.The teen was due to have surgery to repair the hernia, but it was postponed due to school commitments.Testicular torsion occurs when a testicle rotates, twisting the spermatic cord that brings blood to the scrotum.The reduced blood flow causes sudden and often severe pain and swelling.Testicular torsion is most common between ages  and , but it can occur at any age, even before birth.Testicular torsion usually requires emergency surgery.If treated quickly, the testicle can usually be saved.But when blood flow has been cut off for too long, a testicle might become so badly damaged that it has to be removed.Symptoms:Cause:It is not clear why it occurs.Most males who get testicular torsion have an inherited trait that allows the testicle to rotate freely inside the scrotum.Testicular torsion often occurs several hours after vigorous activity, a minor injury to the testicles or sleep.Cold temperature or rapid growth of the testicle during puberty also might play a role.Complications:When it is not treated it can cause damage or death to the testicle due to blocked blood flow.In some cases it can cause infertility.As the testicle is the organ responsible for producing sperm, any damage to them can impact a mans ability to have children.Source: Mayo ClinicBut during his wait for surgery the hernia began to cut off blood supply to his balls and his right testicle twisted  degrees - thats three quarters of the way around.Testicular torsion is common in teens aged between  and , andits not caught early can result in the testicle needing to be amputated.Doctors at Dayton Childrens Hospital in Ohio, US, noticed a visible bulge in his groin and his testicle was exquisitely painful to touch, according to the British Medical Journal case report.Medics were able to untwist the boys testicle with their hands after making an incision on the right-hand side of his scrotum.His hernia required surgery.The teenager recovered well and was discharged the following day.Our patient presented with worsening groin pain and a pre-existing diagnosis of an omentum-containing right inguinal hernia [a hernia that folds into the peritoneum], Dr Arturo Aranda wrote in the case report.The most obvious assessment was that this hernia had become incarcerated [trapped in the abdominal wall].Yet on physical examination, his high-riding testicle and exquisite tenderness prompted a more thorough investigation with ultrasound that confirmed decreased blood flow to the testicle.Early diagnosis can potentially be the dference between saving the testicle or its loss.Ultrasound should be performed early so that manual reduction can be attempted prior to surgical intervention.In our case, this provided immediate relief for the patient, and an intra-operative discovery of a  degree torsion, which is in a range correlative with testicular salvage.Had we successfully reduced our patients’ inguinal hernia in the emergency department, a  sense of security could have easily delayed our operative intervention until morning.Because of clinical suspicion and a testicular ultrasound, we knew that delay was not an option. This further supports the recommendation that all patients with inguinal and testicular pain should undergo ultrasound before any decision to delay surgery is made.

title: angela merkel step down german chancellor 2021
story: The veteran politician has faced calls from within her own Christian Democratic Partyto give up after they were given a drubbing in regional elections.Her predecessor, Gerhard Schroeder, stepped down as leader of his party in  but remained chancellor.Merkel has led the CDU since  and has been Germanys leader since .In the past she has firmly stated that Chancellor should also be a party leader but todays events appear to indicate a change of heart.The CDU haemorrhaged votes, losing more than  per cent of its support, with the Greens and far-right Alternative for Germanymaking big gains.Merkels decision to let in more than a million migrants in  deeply ided the country and helped spark an election backlash.German politics expert Nina Schick told The Sun: “This fast tracks her exit. It makes me think even more that shes not going to serve the entire term.Shes not going to do a Margaret Thatcher or Helmut Kohl where you hang on and on. Shes preparing to go. Theres going to be a vacuum when she leaves.Ms Shick said the news was really bad for French President Emmanuel Macron who has been relying on Merkels help to reform the shaky eurozone.But it will have virtually no impact on the Brexit talks except to leave Berlin even less engaged on what is already a peripheral topic.The CDU is due to hold a conference in December at which the partys leadership is up for renewal.Her party came first in yesterdays election in the western state of Hesse but support fell by more than  points.The embattled -year-old is also having to contend with pressure from her Social Democratjunior coalition partners, who have bled support in Hesse and are under pressure to rethink their alliance with Merkel.SPD leader Andrea Nahles, whose party saw support fall to its lowest since , has threatened to end the alliance with the CDUthere is no improvement on policy.Standing down from the party chair would allow a new CDU chairman or woman to build a profile before the next national election, due in .Merkels favoured successor is CDU party secretary general Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer.Merkels coalition was twice on the brink of collapse, once over immigration policy and then over a dispute about the fate of the domestic intelligence chief who was accused of harbouring far-right views.The instability has further eroded the credibility of the conservatives and the SPD in the eyes of Germans.She currently governs Germany in a grand coalition of what traditionally have been the countrys biggest parties the CDU, its Baia-only sister, the Christian Social Union, and the Social Democrats.Her fourth-term government took only took office in March but has become notorious for internal squabbling.Yesterdays election in the central state of Hesse saw both Merkels conservative Christian Democratic Union and the centre-left Social Democrats lose signicant ground, while there were gains for both the Greens and the far-right Alternative for Germany.Merkels party managed an unimpressive win, narrowly salvaging a majority for its regional governing coalition with the Greens.The debacle followed a battering in a state election in Baia two weeks ago for the CSU and the Social Democrats.The Social Democrats leader, Andrea Nahles, demanded Sunday a clear, binding timetable for implementing government projects before the coalition faces an already-agreed midterm review next fall.Nahles declined to comment Monday on the reports that Merkel might step down as CDU leader. story: Full-time mum Nikki Furness-Winmill, , was enjoying some drinks with friend Vicki Webb, , in Blandford Forum, Dorset, earlier this month when the pair snapped a few selfies on the dance-floor of The Greyhound pub.But it wasn’t until the next morning when the spooked pals allegedly discovered the terrying outline of a ghostly male face appear to be leaning over their shoulders.The women first thought they had been photobombed by another reveller but soon realised the creepy face did not seem human.Neither can explain what the face in the picture was, and they claim it still remains a mystery.Mum-of-one Nikki said: We were on the dance floor when we took a few pictures with my phone.“The first thing I thought was that someone had photobombed us.But the more I looked at it, the more it didnt seem right.Her friend Vicki, a neighbourhood officer, from Norwich said: It was at the end of the night, when we got home that Nikki had sent me the photos from the evening and as I looked through them that particular one made me laugh, I thought someone had photobombed us.It was only when I showed Nikki in the morning that we realised how creepy and weird it looked.Nikki got in touch with Paranormal Investigations UK, where they ran some tests confirming the ghostly authenticity of the picture.She has since discovered The Greyhound was rebuilt in  after a huge fire which claimed lives - so she believes the building could be haunted.Nikki added: I have no idea what it might be. title: angela merkel chancellor germany resigns party chairman cdu election losses
story: She has also said she is leaving the position of Chairman in her own party in December - heres what you need to know.Angela Merkel was born Angela Kasner in Hamburg in July .Her father - a Lutheran pastor - was given a parish in a small town in Communist East Germany and the family moved when she was an infant.After growing up in a rural area outside Berlin and earned a doctorate in physics, she later worked as a chemist at a scientic academy in East Berlin.She married fellow student Ulrich Merkel in  but orced four years later.Merkel met Berlin chemistry professor from Joachim Sauer in  and the couple married privately in . They do not have any children.On October , Angela Merkel announced she would not seek re-election as Chancellor of Germany in .She also said that shes known since the summer break that she no longer wanted to be the CDU chairman and that she will not run again for the position in December.The announcement follows a crushing blow in regional elections in which the party haemorrhaged votes, losing more than  per cent of its support, with the Greens and far-right alternative for Germany making big gains.Its thought voters have punished Merkel over her decision to let in more than a million migrants in  - a move that deeply ided the country.Merkel told reporters that being Chancellor has been a very challenging and fulfilling task.According to CNN, she told reporters: It is time today for me to start a new chapter.This fourth term is my last term as Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany.In the next Bundestag election in , I will not run again as Chancellor.I will not run for the German Bundestag any more, and I do not want any other political office. Angela Merkel has been the Chancellor of Germany since  and the leader of the Christian Democratic Union since .The -year-old outgoing leader has been described in the past as the de facto leader of the European Union and the most powerful woman in the world.Merkel decision to resign could spark a race within the CDU to find her successor as chancellor, a position which is usually determined in Germanys federal elections.The next federal elections are provisionally scheduled for .Its thought that CDU General Secretary Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer could replace Merkel as Chancellor of Germany.

title: chancellor philip hammond budget speech commons
story: The Chancellor vowed to back the strivers, the grafters and the carers who are the backbone of our economy as he laid out his tax and spending plans for the next year.Mr Hammond has said thatwe crash out of the EU without a deal, he will hold an emergency Budget aimed at shoring up the economy.But No insisted that the announcements made in the Budget today would apply whether or not Britain strikes a deal with the EU.Mrs Mays spokesman said: We are focused on delivering irrespective of Brexit, starting with todays Budget which locks in the progress we have made.All of the spending commitments that the Chancellor will set out today are funded irrespective of a deal.Labours John McDonnell blasted: What is going on  The PM and the Chancellor contradicting each other. On the day of the Budget. We’ve never seen anything like this.The PM has claimed that austerity is coming to an end in a hint that tax cuts and spending boosts could be on the way.But the Chancellor - nicknamed Spreadsheet Phil - is keen to drive down the deficit by keeping the purse-strings tight.Brits were watching out for expected income tax cuts, with the tax-free personal allowance likely to be raised.Business rates were also set to be cut for small firms, while the VAT threshold is likely to be frozen in another boost to entrepreneurs.And hard-pressed motorists will welcome a freeze to fuel duty, which follows a long-running Sun campaign.But there was expected to be bad news for pension savers with the amount they can store up tax-free set to be cut.On the spending front, the biggest expense was expected to be a £billion cash boost to the NHS.There could also be more money ploughed in to Universal Credit - providing relief to benefits claimants whove been squeezed by the roll-out of the new system.And victims of the payday loans cowboys will get a helping hand from a scheme to provide interest-free cash to Brits who cant repay their existing debts.Other Budget highlights include:Todays setpiece event could be the Chancellors last Budget.He is widely expected to be pushed aside either by Mrs May or by a possible new Tory leader within the next year.Mr Hammond is under pressure to keep up the progress towards driving down the deficit - while also easing the public spending squeeze.Treasury officials have been frustrated by the dficulty of introducing new tax hikes or spending cuts while the Government lacks a majority in Parliament.A source told The Sun: All the ideas we had over the summer to increase revenue have been vetoed because theyre too politically tricky.Even the easiest stuff has been ruled out in the current environment - ministers dont want to rock the boat.Brexiteer Tories and DUP MPs have previously threatened to vote down the Budget in protest at Mrs Mays Chequers plans.Todays Budget is the first to be held on a Monday for more than half a century.The speech usually takes place on a Wednesday - story: And then, just as we were getting used to Raksriaksorn, it changed again to something even more unpronounceable. But we did that at Leicester City Football Club. We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha not just for who he was - but because of who he wasnt.We loved him not only for what he did - but what he didnt do. When he arrived at Leicester in the summer of , he bought the club from Milan Mandaric. There was concern in some quarters that because Mandaric had sealed the deal then maybe this new Thai chap was cut from the same cloth.He wasnt.If Mandaric was all about hiring and firing and shooting from the hip in pt back page headlines - and, oh boy, he was - then Khun Vichai, to give him his conventional Thai title, was the opposite of that. title: 5 things philip hammond didnt
story: NewsopinionThe  things Philip Hammond didnt put in his BudgetWhat the Chancellor wont say is far more important than what he promisesShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  OCT Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It is very hard, when hearing a promise, not to believe it. Promises are always so nice, so welcome, so... fantastic. But the best way to handle a smiling assurance - whether its being made by a partner, a plumber or a politician - is to judge them all on what they do, not what they say.Only then do you go back to the promises, and seethey stack up. To be fair, Chancellor Philip Hammond has a hell of a job selling optimism to a nation riven by Brexit, gross inequality, and High Street turmoil. Its even harder when the best he can leak is pothole repair fund, paid for with higher road taxes. And things change. The world is always in flux, which means even the most decent of politicians may find it impossible to deliver on a pledge they once genuinely thought possible.But thats no excuse for all the things Hammond should be telling you, but isnt. What people dont say is far more important than what they do, and hes left some very important things out of his budget:. An apology  When the worlds banks crashed in , governments all over the globe stepped in to save them. Not because they like banks - but because in those places where they didnt, mortgages were foreclosed, loans were called in, wages werent paid, suicides increased, and recession sucked at society.The Tories would have done the same,they were in power. They werent, so they blamed Labour for debt that was actually duty, and once in government used it to justy swingeing austerity that cut police funding by a fth, given the NHS a year-round winter crisis and thrown a million extra children into Victorian levels of poverty.Economists warned in  that spending cuts would choke the breath out of a struggling economy - that you must invest in people and businesses to save and make money in the long term. The Tories ignored the logic, and by cutting services increased costs for all of us. Since Hammond became Chancellor two years ago he has been urged repeatedly to turn on the taps, and refused because of that failed, flawed, demonstrably  Tory ideology. Not one damned thing is cheaper or better as a result of austerity. A decent Chancellor would admit it was wrong. . Sanity  The government has spent pound.billion on HS before it even begins, the price keeps being revised upwards and it wont be finished until  at the earliest. The total projected cost is now estimated at pound.bn, which works out to poundm per platinum-plated mile.It has also spent pound.bn over  years on Universal Credit, in which time it has been rolled out to fewer than % of benefit claimants, costs have risen to pound just to process each claim, the DWP has been found guilty of disability discrimination and its been linked to hunger, illness and suicide. Over the same period, the government has been repeatedly warned that its a cock-up, too expensive, and wont save money. Today, Hammond is announcing hes ploughing even more money into something so disastrous it should be renamed Logically Shredded. In gambling, this is known as the sunk cost fallacy - the idea that, because youve thrown so much cash at this already, you cannot stop. Rather than count the price of their lunacy the Tories are claiming thatthey just throw a few more billion at it, theyre bound to win. They are literally playing roulette with your money, while saying theyve got this, its fine, dont want to let the other guy have your money because theyll waste it. They should be in therapy, not government.. A proper concept of time  Every promise in Hammonds speech will be for things that wont happen for years. Years in which other budget promises will overwrite these ones, previous years money will be rationalised downwards, and accounting practices will be shted slightly to make it look like next year will be better than last. Its a bit like promising your family a trip to Boston, and never telling them when it will be, that they will have to pay for it, or that its the Boston in Lincolnshire and not the one in Massachusetts.Itll sound like hes promising you mental health nurses tomorrow - but once hes cut money from something  to pay for it, and recruited  people to work in rotation for -hour shts at every hospital and school in the country, plus holiday cover, well all be dead. . Recycling It has been a little over  months since China refused to take any more of our foreign garbage and in that time the British plastic mountains have been photographed from space.Bales of unrecycled waste are piled up at abandoned airfields and rubbish dumps while councils - which have no money because of that austerity every sane person knew was a bad idea - say it is now too expensive to do anything with.Now increasing amounts of plastic are being incinerated, with parabens hurled into the atmosphere, or buried where they can degrade into tiny toxic balls that get into rivers, soil, animals, food and, oh yes, every human gut.How we deal with waste is dferent for every local authority, but the rules on landfill sites, packaging and recycling targets are all written in Westminster. The nation needs a national recycling strategy, where the same things are collected, in the same bins, in every area and every supermarket and shop has the same rules about minimising packaging and plastic. Its not dficult, stupid or expensive. It just takes someone with the guts to suggest a fresh idea, rather than the same empty promises they made last time. . Reality  Hammonds promises all depend on  things: A Guesstimates B Bad eyesight C Brexit not being badUnfortunately, guesstimates butter no parsnips, theres always at least one financial journalist in spectacles going through the small print, and Brexit is considered to be A Bad Thing by car manufacturers, fishermen, farmers, the financial services industry, academics, and anyone who wants to go on holiday somewhere other than Skegness. Even Nigel Farage has admitted it could be doomed, which means this budget is too.A Budget is nothing more than nail nish. A way to pretty the overall animal, and make you look at the tips rather than the body. Ultimately the best test is to seethe paints been chipped off by some serious journalism by this time next week, enabling you to notice the ragged, snaggly ends of the Tory superiority complex.Ask yourself this -the Chancellor was a plumber or your partner, would you believe him  Or would you be distracted enough by his joke about a p coin to keep him in his job

story: NewsAngela Merkel is to stand down as German chancellor in  - and the Euro has tumbledThe CDU leader told party leaders she will not stand to be chairwoman of the Christian Democrats - but is said to want to remain ChancellorShareCommentsByJoseph NasrAndreas RinkeAnn Gripper:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAngela Merkels CDU have suffered poor local election results "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Merkel has said this will be her final term as German chancellor confirming that she will not run in . She confirmed today her fourth term as chancellor would be her last, heralding the end of a -year era in which she has dominated European politics. Merkel, , has been chairwoman of her conservative Christian Democratssince  and chancellor since . She is also giving up the CDU role in December, starting a race within the party to succeed her. Standing down from the party chair would allow a new CDU chairman or woman to build a profile before the next national election, due in . The Euro fell after the news emerged. Merkel had today faced calls from her own party to stand down as leader after poor local election results. Merkels Christian Democratswon Sundays election in the western state of Hesse but support fell by more than  points. The CDU is reliant on an alliance with the centre-left Social Democrats, the SPD, who are coming under pressure of their own. Their support is falling as they suffer in coalition.  SPD leader Andrea Nahles, whose party saw support fall to its lowest since , has threatened to end the alliance with Merkels conservativesthere is no improvement on policy. Merkels weakness at home may limit her capacity to lead in the European Union at a time when the bloc is dealing with Brexit, a budget crisis in Italy and the prospect of populist parties making gains at European parliament elections next May. Merkel, chancellor for  years, will have to invest her political capital and tactical acumen to keep together her loveless coalition, borne out of necessity seven months ago after an inconclusive federal election last year. The CDUs Christian von Steffen said bluntly: We need a meaningful programme with a clear path and new faces. Merkels favoured successor is said to be CDU party secretary general Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer.  CDU leaders will meet next Sunday to prepare for a summit in December where party members will vote for a new chairman. Nahles is also feeling the heat from SPD members still disgruntled with their leaders decision to join Merkel instead of fulfilling an election promise to sit in oppositionthey fail to win the federal vote. Nahles said on Sunday she would propose a roadmap to allow the SPD to measure the progress of the ruling coalition, which has been plagued by infighting, at a mid-term review next year. Her proposal did little to appease the head of the SPDs youth wing, who said the election in Hesse was a clear signal that the ruling coalition was not viable. The final verdict on the coalition has been spoken, Kevin Kuehnert wrote in Twitter. Voters dont want business as usual. Merkels coalition was twice on the brink of collapse, once over immigration policy and then over a dispute about the fate of the domestic intelligence chief who was accused of harbouring far-right views.  The instability has further eroded the credibility of the conservatives and the SPD in the eyes of German voters, who are increasingly turning to smaller parties on the right and on the left. In Hesse, where Merkels CDU rule with the ecologist Greens, the two biggest winners were the Greens and the far-right Alternative for Germany .

The world is always in flux, which means even the most decent of politicians may find it impossible to deliver on a pledge they once genuinely thought possible.But that#xs no excuse for all the things Hammond should be telling you, but isn#xt. What people don#xt say is far more important than what they do, and he#xs left some very important things out of his budget.:Mikey SmithReaction to Hammonds payday loan planDebt charity Step Change have responded to Philip Hammond#xs plan for alternatives to payday loans, and help for people with problem debt.You can read the full details of the policy hereStepChange Director of External Affairs Richard Lane comments on the idea of a no-interest loan scheme:Having campaigned for years for a no-interest loan scheme, we#xre looking forward to working with the government and the banks to bring it to le. Over a million people turned to high cost credit last year to meet basic living expenses, which is counterproductive both for households and the economy. If finances are tight and your fridge breaks down, the last thing you need is expensive credit - what you need is simply a replacement fridge. By taking away the additional high cost of borrowing, the new scheme will demonstrate how no interest loans can act as a realistic and better alternative to short term high cost credit. It can only be a good thing to reduce the risk of households building up problem debt as a result of trying to meet their basic needs.On breathing space, he adds:The fact that breathing space is being introduced is a great step forward, but it#xs vital that the government listens carefully to responses on how the scheme design should be finalised . There are three crucial elements still at stake. First, all debts and enforcement activity #x including debts owed to government #x need to be included in the breathing space. Second, there needs to be flexibility to extend the -day time periodnecessary, to avoid the risk of people who are in the process of sorting out their debts being put back to square onetime runs out before this process is complete. And third, the administration of the scheme needs to be proportionate, using the existing expertise of partner debt advice charities, to avoid becoming bogged down in expensive bureaucracy.:Mikey SmithHammonds fiscal firepowerAsked whether Mrs May agreed with the Chancellor that an emergency Budget might be needed in the springthere is no deal, the PM#xs spokesman said: What the Chancellor said yesterday was that he would use the fiscal reserves that we have built up through hard work and sound economic management to ensure that Britain will succeed whatever the circumstances.The Chancellor has spoken on numerous occasions about having maintained what he would describe as #xfiscal firepower#x which he will be able to use in the event of a no-deal scenario.He added:What the Chancellor was pointing out in relation to a budget was thateconomic circumstances change, he would consider economic interventions. That#xs what you would expect any sensible Chancellor to do.Asked whether the end of austerity was contingent on getting a good Brexit deal, the PM#xs spokesman said: We#xve been clear that people need to know that their hard work has paid off and that the austerity that followed the financial crash is coming to an end.That#xs why we are focused on delivering irrespective of Brexit, starting with today#xs Budget which locks in the progress we have made and sets us on a path for the Spending Review, where we will set out our long-term approach.All of the spending commitments that the Chancellor will set out today are funded irrespective of a deal.So that#xs cleared that up then.:Mikey SmithEnd of austerity still on, insists Number Some more detail from this morning#xs Number  briefing - where Theresa May#xs spokesperson insisted the end of austerity is still on, no matter what happens with Brexit - and regardless of what the Chancellor said yesterday.We#xve been clear that people need to know that their hard work has paid off and that the austerity that followed the financial crash is coming to an end. That#xs why we are focused on delivering irrespective of Brexit, starting with today#xs Budget which locks in the progress we have made and sets us on a path for the Spending Review, where we will set out our long-term approach. All of the spending commitments that the Chancellor will set out today are funded irrespective of a deal.:Mikey SmithDeputy Speaker Lindsay Hoyle is an epic teaseDeputy Commons Speaker and EPIC TEASE Lindsay Hoyle shows off about getting a sneak peak at the Budget.:KEY EVENTTheresa May slaps down her own Chancellor in last-minute clash over BrexitTheresa May appears to have slapped down her own Chancellor, Philip Hammond - four hours before he delivers his budget.Word out of the Number  briefing is that #xCall spending commitments that the Chancellor is going to outline today are funded, irrespective of a Brexit deal.#xDQuite apart from that clearly being nonsense, it directly contradicts what Hammond said, repeatedly, on the telly yesterday morning.Askedhis budget would stand evenBritain doesn#xt get a deal, he told Sky News:If we were to find ourselves in that situation then we would need to take a dferent approach to the future of Britain#xs economy.We would need to look at a dferent strategy. And frankly we#xd need to have a new budget that set out a dferent strategy for the future.He explained his Budget is based on the OBR#xs forecasts, which are working on the assumption we#xll get a deal. If we don#xt, he says, we#xll have to think again.Awkward.:Everything thats missing from the new plan to stop problem debtThis year#xs Budget is trying hard to tackle problem debt - with three initiatives set to be included to help people in need and crack down on high-cost loans.But given one of the biggest sources of problem debt right now is, well, the Government - the plans we#xve seen so far swing wildly from irrelevant to at best problematic. story: NewsBrit backpacker battered to a pulp and left for dead in Australia by crowbar-wielding taxi driverWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Euan Fraser, , says he suffered a bleed on the brain after being brutally beaten unconscious on the doorstep of a Melbourne homeShareCommentsBySophie EvansJack Longstaff:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEuan Fraser, , is pictured in hospital after the attack in June last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British backpacker claims he was left for dead in Australia after being battered unconscious by a crowbar-wielding cabbie.Euan Fraser, , says the taxi driver beat him to a pulp on the doorstep of a Melbourne home where he was living at the time.After being knocked clean out, he claims he suffered further blows while lying on the floor before being left in a pool of blood. He suffered a bleed on the brain, but fortunately survived.Police are now investigating the circumstances surrounding the assault last year, which left a terried Euan soaked in blood.The young man, from Dundee, Scotland, recalled: As I got out of the taxi I just heard footsteps behind me and heard a loud bang.  Then I felt this immense pain in my head and I was knocked clean out. I was laid into when I was on the floor.I was left laying there in a pool of blood. He left me for dead. I woke up with blood in my eyes and my clothes were soaked. I stumbled into the kitchen and it looked like a murder scene. I had never seen so much blood. My whole body was in agony.I was so scared. He added: I needed  stitches on my face and I had a few broken ribs, a dislocated shoulder and a bleed on the brain. It has totally changed my le forever. Euan, who stands ft ins tall, claims the attack happened following what he thought was a harmless discussion about religion.  Medics reportedly carried out tests which showed he was struck with a thick metal pole, like a crowbar, during the attack. He says he was forced to shell out pound, for his medical treatment and now suffers with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder . I keep reliving what happened in my head, he said. I will never be the same again. Euan who was working on a farm at the time, had flagged down the yellow cab after a night out with a friend in Melbourne in June . He claims the driver became visibly annoyed when he said he was an atheist and when he expressed his views about religion. The architecture student recalled: He didnt like it at all when I started expressing my views... I tried to change the conversation but he kept going on about it. I could see he was getting wound up.  It was after Euan had got out of the car in Aberfeldie, in the early hours of June  that year, that the attack allegedly occurred.He claims that he was expecting the cabbie to drive off when he was suddenly smashed over the head and beaten to a pulp. When he woke up, he recalls having pain all over his body and believes the driver battered him as he laid unresponsive on the pavement. He stumbled into his home before collapsing on the kitchen floor. Euan claims he suffered bruised ribs, a battered shoulder and multiple cuts to his face, as well as the bleed on the brain, in the attack. He called an Uber to Melbournes Sunshine Hospital following the incident, where he stayed for around a week.He says he was forced to borrow money from friends to pay for a pound, medical bill. And he was treated on a specialist mental health ward after he started experiencing suicidal thoughts.  He travelled home to his family a few weeks after the attack. More than a year on, Euan has only just felt able to speak out. He has been reimbursed for his medical bills and awarded pound, in injury compensation by the Australian government. However, cops have yet to trace the taxi driver - and Euan says he is petried to step foot in a taxi, with his confidence shattered.The young man, who lives with his girlfriend, Sharon Macrae, , says he has been left mentally scarred and suffers with PTSD. He said: It has left me in a terrible place and has totally changed my le. I used to be a really confident person but since the attack I have terrible nightmares. It has seriously affected my mental health. Whenever I think about it I get upset. It was just absolutely shocking.  I just cant believe that someone would do that to me. Im a big guy, ft in tall and  stone, and I never thought anyone would be capable of that. Ill be stuck with PTSD for le. I wake up screaming and shouting in the night quite a lot. A Melbourne Police spokesperson said: Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding an assault in Aberfeldie on  June, . It is believed a man was standing outside his home address on Fawkner Street in the early hours of the morning when he was struck in the back of the head by an unknown offender. The victim, -years-old at the time, sustained serious head injuries. The victim reported having a verbal altercation with a taxi driver prior to the incident. Investigators have not identied the offender at this stage and the investigation remains ongoing. Anyone with information has been urged to contact Crime Stoppers on    or submit a confidential report at www.crimestoppersvic.au If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

title: doctors give devastating news parents
story: NewsDoctors give devastating news to parents of toddler who kept tilting head to leftMum Zoe Archer, , knew something wasnt right with Alisha Riley after spotting her daughters unusual behaviourShareCommentsByKate McMullin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAlisha Riley in her new specialist buggy after her treatment, provided to her by Newle charity "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated mother has told of how her toddler twin daughter kept tilting her head to left before being diagnosed with a deadly brain tumour. Mum Zoe Archer knew something wasnt right with Alisha Riley after spotting the unusual behaviour. And she trusted her instincts and took the little girl to the doctors where, after tests and scans, it was confirmed Alisha had a cancerous brain tumour. Zoe, from Huyton, Merseyside, first noticed the symptom in February when her daughter was  months old. The -year-old said Alisha, who has a twin brother Jack, was crawling when she saw the youngster was tilting her head to the left She told the Liverpool Echo: It was only slightly but she did it for a few days and I just thought she may have a bit of a stf neck. She wasnt crying with it and it wasnt stuck in that position. However days later Alisha began to vomit and the mum took her to AE.  She underwent a number of tests at both Alder Hey and Whiston Hospital which came back clear. But when she continued to deteriorate Alisha was given a scan - which is when doctors dealt the devastating blow that the youngster had a brain tumour. Zoe said: I knew she wasnt right. It was like she had gone back to being a two-month-old. I had to prop up cushions around her. It was like she was dizzy. Her eyes would roll and she wasnt able to keep down anything - she would just throw up. When they said it was a tumour it felt like my heart had stopped. I just looked at Alisha and started crying. Alisha was rushed to Alder Hey where doctors told her family she had a cm by cm tumour - the size of a golf ball. The tumour was located in her posterior fossa - an area in the brain responsible for critical s such as breathing, balance, speaking and co-ordination. Doctors firstly drained the fluid in Alishas brain and days later she had to undergo a nine hour surgery to remove the tumour. Zoe said: It just all wasnt really registering with me. Doctors were telling me of the risks of surgery and that my tiny baby could die. I was trying to listen, but it just wasnt going in. Although the surgery was a success, Alisha was not recovering as fast as doctors would have hoped and another scan showed the devastating reason why.  Alisha had a cancerous grade three brain tumour called an Ependymoma - which would grow back. Zoe said: We couldnt believe it. We had been happy because the surgery had been a success and had thought - the tumour had been removed so the cancer had been removed. The family were given a number of options including radiotherapy and chemotherapy - but due to her age both treatments came with their risks. Another option was a specialist treatment called proton beam therapy in Florida. And in June the family made the decision to fly to America for  weeks - in a bid to save their daughters le. A Go Fund me page, launched by Zoes brother Lee, raised more than pound, for the family - for their costs while out there. And after  rounds of treatment this week the family were given the fantastic news that Alishas scan was clear of cancer. Zoe said: I am so proud of how she has handled everything. She just kept smiling. Doctors have said she is about a year behind with her development, but she is getting there. She is learning to crawl again and Jack and her are playing together again. He has been great with her and will get down on the floor and crawl with her to get her going. Alisha has also been helped to move around by Newle - a charity for disabled children. Newle runs the only emergency loan service for children providing urgently needed, specialist equipment within hours, and provided a specialist buggy for Alisha. Zoe added: Because of her condition Alisha can’t sit up or support her own head, so she needs a specialist buggy with extra head support and chest straps to keep her in a stable position. Without that to keep her safe we couldn’t go. Now Alisha and her twin, Jack, are getting ready to celebrate their second birthday at the end of October. Le’s definitely not been easy and Alisha will have to have another scan in January, but we are over the moon. I think every time a scan is coming up we are going to be anxious. But now I will know the symptoms to look out for.

story: NewsDoctors say new mums should wait a YEAR before getting pregnant again to avoid fatal birth complicationsNew research has revealed that pregnancies with a gap of just six months were at higher risk of becoming a premature labourShareCommentsByHana Carter:,  OCT NewsThe study was conducted on , births by experts at University British Columbia and Hard"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNew mums who become pregnant less than a year after giving birth could be putting themselves and their unborn baby in danger. The discovery was made by experts at University of British Columbiaand the Hard TH Chan School of Public heath - who studied , births in Canada. According to researchers, parents who waited  to  months after their first child reduced the risk short and long term risks to both mum and baby. Whereas parents who had a little time between pregnancies were at risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity. The researchers found a short gap between pregnancies affected mothers aged over , while risks to the infant were found for all women - particularly for those aged  to .  Laura Schummers, a post-doctoral fellow at the UBC, said: Our study found increased risks to both mother and infant when pregnancies are closely spaced, including for women older than . The findings for older women are particularly important, as older women tend to more closely space their pregnancies and often do so intentionally. The study is the described by the authors as the most extensive evaluation of how the role of pregnancy spacing could be impacted by maternal age. It is also the first investigation of pregnancy spacing and maternal mortality or severe morbidity - rare but le-threatening complications of pregnancy, labour and delivery - in a high-income country, the authors said.  Among women over  who conceived six months after a previous birth, the researchers found a .% risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity.Waiting  months between pregnancies, however, reduced the risk to .%, the authors said. For younger women, the researchers found an .% risk of spontaneous preterm birth - delivery before  weeks of pregnancy after labour that started on its own - for pregnancies spaced at six months. For younger women who waited  months between pregnancies, however, the risk dropped to .%. Senior author Dr Wendy Norman, UBC associate professor, said: Achieving that optimal one-year interval should be doable for many women, and is clearly worthwhile to reduce complication risks.

title: mum student hannah cornelius who
story: NewsMum of student Hannah Cornelius who was raped and murdered was found dead waiting for trial to beginAnna Cornelius, , set up the Hannah Cornelius Foundation to remember her daughterShareCommentsByGrace Witherden:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mum of a -year-old student who was raped and murdered in South Africa tragically drowned months before her alleged attackers went on trial. Anna Cornelius died in March this year, less than a year after her daughter Hannah Cornelius was killed. Four men are currently standing trial at Western Cape Court and face charges of rape and murder. In a Facebook post titled When Anna joined Hannah, the Hannah Cornelius Foundation confirmed that Anna died on Sunday, March . Her body was seen floating in shallow water by beachgoers in Scarborough, Cape Town. It said: Anna’s friends and family knew her as an amazing human being, full of light, abundant love and energy. Following her daughter, Hannah’s, death Anna founded the Hannah Cornelius Foundation in June .  It said: Anna was driven to ensure that Hannah’s legacy be remembered through her acts of goodwill, forgiveness and love. Through the Hannah Cornelius Foundation, Anna wished to support other young people to reach beyond the realities of their present circumstances and achieve their dreams through hard work, commitment and a passionate dedication to their own development. Anna was a lawyer and leaves behind her husband, magistrate Willem Cornelius, and son, Dries.  The Hannah Cornelius Foundation aims to help underprivileged children access the opportunities “Hannah had in her le” by offering‚ among other things‚ trauma counselling and help with unplanned pregnancies. Hannah Cornelius was carjacked by four men while dropping off fellow student Cheslin Marsh, , at his home in Stellenbosch, east of Cape Town, after a night out in May . Vernon Witbooi, , Geraldo Parsons, , Nashville Julius, , and Eben Van Nieberk, , face a string of charges including murder, kidnap, robbery and rape of the Stellenbosch University student.  One of the alleged attackers claimed Hannah told the gang they could have sex with herthey let her go afterwards. Parsons said he raped Ms Cornelius first, followed by Witbooi and then van Niekerk. He claims he tried to get them to release Hannah but they put her in the boot and drove her to a vineyard.  The court heard Hannah went through an “extremely painful” ordeal before she was killed. Hannah suffered severe vaginal and cervical injuries in the prolonged attack. The court heard how Parsons had plastic pearls embedded in his penis which would likely have made the sex attack more painful.Heavy bruising on her arms show she had been held down and it is believed that probably several of the gang lted the huge rock and dropped it on her head.  At an earlier hearing, it emerged that Hannahs parents were sent a letter from one of her alleged gang-rapists begging for their forgiveness. Eben van Niekerk penned the letter but claims he was told to write in by Sergeant Steven Adams. The letter was reportedly written after his arrest and before the four men first appeared in court. It was translated from Afrikaans and had a number of errors. The top of the letter says: This letter comes from Eben VNK and it was also signed and initialled.  When translated, the letter reads: Herewith I write this letter to Hennas mom and dad. I am sorry for what I did and I askthey can forgive me for what I have done… The girl was like a friend to me but the other accused, I was also scared of them and it wasnt nice to see. I was also scared of them. Dont be angry at me please .

story: NewsWhy pregnant Meghan Markle sat behind men including Harry during New Zealand Maori welcomeFeminist Meghan, who is pregnant with her and Harrys first child, sat several inches back from her husband and other men at the ceremonyShareCommentsByRussell MyersSophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video meghan-harry-discuss-mental-health-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry both had seats of honour today as they received a traditional Maori welcome in New Zealand.But while the couple were seated on the front row for the ceremony, the Duchess of Sussex was placed slightly behind her husband.Feminist Meghan, who is pregnant with her and Harrys first child, sat several inches back from him and other men on either side of her. However, there was a reason for this - the arrangement is a sign of protection for women, particularly those who are pregnant, in the initial meeting between iwi, the tribe, and new visitors.  Traditionally the meeting could be a moment of “war” and is an opportunity to air grievances. Barney Thomas, chief elder, explained: “We never ever put our women in that space. “We want to be inclusive but protective, and we would not want to put our women - especially the Duchess because she’s expecting - at risk.” The meeting, of course, went without a hitch, with warm wishes from both hosts and visitors, a welcoming song and, finally, food. The Duke and Duchess had travelled by helicopter to the stunning Abel Tasman national park to enjoy the hospitality of the Maori people.  The couple, who are expecting their first child in the Spring, flew over forests, valleys and clear blue waters before arriving to drizzle.They were welcomed by songs, prayers, countless traditional “hongi” greetings and a banquet of food from their new friends. The ceremony was accompanied by the blowing of a conch shell. Following their arrival, the couple and their entourage made their way along a line of around  hosts, shaking each by the hand. They also performed the gentle nose kiss.  They were then invited to sit in two rows of plastic seats opposite the iwi with their all-female royal household staff in the back row and the Duke, Duchess and their two male translators in the front. Mr Thomas gave a speech of welcome in Maori, followed by a waiata, a song, from the group. “We’ve been watching your tour and we know you don’t get much time off,” Mr Thomas said. “I wouldn’t want to be a royal. So we don’t want to put any demands on you. We want you to enjoy yourself.All we want you to do is relax.”  The Duke, , struck an upbeat tone despite the drizzly weather, which cancelled a tree-planting ceremony. He and Meghan,  stayed inside a dry marquee for tea and cake with schoolchildren. Speaking after being formally welcomed by the Manawhenua ki Mohua people, Harry shared his excitement about visiting with a baby on board. He said: “The weather forecast was a lot worse than this. This rain is a blessing on all of us.From myself and my we and our little bump, we are so grateful to be here. “We bring blessings from my grandmother the Queen and our family. “We are so grateful for your hospitality and the work you do to look after this beautul place.”  The couple also strolled along the golden-sand beachfront on the nations South Island and discussed conservation with a ranger. Harry, wearing a black puffer jacket, and Meghan, dressed in a black Seasalt coat, came across a weka, a small flightless native bird. Ranger Andrew Lamason told the pair that the creature is New Zealands version of a monkey due to its cheeky nature. Teenager Saskia Gray, a youth ambassador, said she was impressed by the Duke and Duchess. They acted very down-to-earth, and they genuinely care about the people and the land, said the -year-old. The couple later boarded their Royal New Zealand Air Force helicopter laden with gts, including a knitted blanket fit for a newborn baby.
