title: voice star paul black reveals
story: NewsThe Voice star Paul Black reveals how tattoos helped stop him self harming to numb pain of daughter Pearls deathPaul Black, from Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales, lost -month-old Pearl in on August  - after a Range Rover rolled off its driveway into a wall which crushed herShareCommentsByDavid OwensAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video pearl-blacks-parents-speak-first-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA star of The Voice who lost his -month-old daughter when she was crushed to death in an accident caused by a rolling car has revealed how he used tattooes to stop himself self-harming to numb the pain. Paul and Gemma Black, from Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales, lost little Pearl on on August ,  - when a Range Rover rolled off its driveway, across a road and demolished a wall which crushed her. The parents have spoken out about the pain they will feel for the rest of their lives, and how not a second in the day passes where they dont grieve for their daughter. Now, Paul, who appeared on the TV talent show in , has undergone extensive tattoos all over his body in a bid to numb the pain - and has even come as close to self harm, reports Wales Online. He described how while using a razor to shave his head, he would dig the blade in to see his own blood. Speaking about his loss and heartbreak, Paul said: Ive used tattooing as my therapy, he said. Its literally been therapy for me because when I sit in that chair, for that amount of time, be it five hours, seven hours, everything goes away. I get into a meditative state. When Im getting tattooed its the only time that everything goes away.  For me I shut my eyes and I dont feel the pain anymore. Its become a huge part of my recovery process. Im nearly done now, Im nearly covered. He did, however, confess that he did start cutting himself but quickly stopped. When my head was shaved I did start to cut myself with a razor. I would stand in a mirror and experience the feeling of the razor going into my head so I could see the blood. I realised quickly that I was spoiling the tattoos. Ive never self-harmed until I shaved my head but I would imagine the tattooing is the closest thing that I would imagine someone who self-harms feels. But as I say it does help me through it. Theres no blood. Its nothing to do with the pain. Its that purely meditative state that I get in when Im being tattooed and I can sit for hours. All the other pain goes away. The former singer said he replays the moment Pearl was hit by the wall over and over in his mind every day. As a result he has been diagnosed with severe Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder . People see me walking down the street and they think I am confident because of this exterior and bravado, but I am absolutely crumbling inside, he said.  I defy any man living to see what Ive seen. No man will see their child getting crushed to death in front of them. No man has seen what Ive seen. He was forced to relive the tragic circumstances leading to his daughters death at the inquest this week and at one point could not bear to say the words out loud. In his heartbreaking evidence he recounted the events leading up to the tragedy and detailed the extraordinary s he went to in a bid to save his two children, Pearl and Ace. He told the court how when the vehicle careered towards him building up speed he threw Ace into the road and tried to step in front of Pearl, but wasn’t quick enough to throw her as well. “The Range Rover proceeded to crush her in front of me, he said. The weight of the wall. She was so small. “I’d rather not go into severe details. There was so much blood. “There was a lot of blood spraying. I could see the death just appearing on her face. “I lted the wall off her. I don’t know how I done it. I was saying: ‘Come back to daddy.’ She was literally limp and leless. “I was screaming: ‘She’s gone, she’s gone, my poor baby girl.’ I was covered in blood.” He told how he was so angry he started to smash up the Range Rover.  “There was a hammer lying on the wall, he said. I smashed every single window. I smashed the back window first. Smashed all the windows, the lights, the bonnet. “I was engulfed with pure anger and rage, as I’m sure you can appreciate. “In my mind, it was the vehicle had killed my little girl. In the  months since that day, Gemma said she still cant bear to visit the scene of where it happened near to her mother-in-laws house. “I havent been to my mother-in-laws house since last August,” said Gemma. “I cant turn left out of the house to go up there.” Paul said the hope that there would be justice for his beautul little girl was one of the things keeping him going. But they said they were devastated when they were told there would be no criminal prosecution against the Range Rovers owner Mr Williams. “We were distraught when the police told us, said Paul.  It was one of the things that was keeping me focused and positive in le - that there would be some sort of justice, some sort of recompense. “Nothing will ever make up for what has happened. No amount of justice would have been right for what has happened to Pearl but it was a huge blow.” The inquest at Pontypridd Coroners Court ruled that Pearls death was an accident. The police investigation had found the car wasnt secure with the handbrake on the empty Range Rover not sufficiently applied. Gemma and Paul are now campaigning for a change to the law, which they say has prevented a charge being brought. “Weve already made grounds to try and get the law changed,” said Gemma. “Weve had a meeting with our local MP Gerald Jones and hes very keen to take it on and to create a private members bill that will be put through Parliament. Were in the process of working through the logistics of this and how we go about this, so thats ongoing.” If you are affected by this story and need to speak to someone, the Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

story: NewsCircus lion pulls girl, four, into ring and sinks teeth into her head mid-performance in horrying footageWARNING- DISTRESSING FOOTAGE AND PHOTOS. The child is in intensive care in Russia after she was left with a bite on her face spanning from her ear to her chin, according to a medicShareCommentsByWill Stewart:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video heart-stopping-moment-circus-lion-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTerrying footage captures the moment a circus lioness lunges at a four-year-old girl in the middle of its act. The horrying video shows how the animal suddenly broke off from performing before it reportedly mauled the helpless child in Russia. One account claimed the lion sank its teeth into the victims head. The young girl, named as Ksenia, is in intensive care with serious face and chest injuries. She survived the incident but doctors say she will be “scarred for le” and a medic says she has been left with a bite mark on her face spanning from her ear to her chin.  The child had been waving a small flag and the lioness rushed from its trainer despite being on a leash and sprang on the child. One account said the wild animal broke a flimsy safety netting around the circus ring at Uspenskoye village in the Krasnodar region. Valentina Pavlova said she was a member of a medical team which treated the girl at the Central Republican Hospital in Krasnodar. “There is a bite on her face that goes from ear to chin,” she said.  She added that the lioness used its paw and pulled the child inside onto the arena and sank its teeth into her head. “The circus team pulled the lioness away and delivered the girl to the Central Republican Hospital. “She is now in stable condition, there is no danger to her le.”  The child is being treated in intensive care. Wild animals continue to be used for performances in Russian circuses, including many touring troupes that go from place to place. The latest incident is likely to lead to increase calls to ban the use of performing predators like lions and bears.

title: dad found no memory searched
story: NewsDad found with no memory searched how to disappear before leaving cryptic codes and £k in briefcaseSalvatore Mannino, , originally from Italy, was discovered in Edinburghs St Giles’ Cathedral - and claimed to Police Scotland that he had no idea who he wasShareByPaul RodgerChris Marshall:,  OCT NewsSalvatore Mannino had also searched the weather in Edinburgh online before he left Italy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father who was found with apparent memory loss had searched how to disappear without a trace before leaving cryptic codes and a briefcase of pound, in cash behind for his family. Salvatore Mannino, , originally from Italy, was discovered in Edinburghs St Giles’ Cathedral - before claiming to Police Scotland that he had no idea who he was. Italian media say police searching for the missing man found searches on his laptop about the best way to disappear without a trace. Searches about the weather in Edinburgh were also found before he left his home country. It was also reported that Mr Mannino tried to close joint bank accounts belonging to him and his we, moving the money to accounts under her name only. He has has now been charged with “violating his family assistance obligations” as a result, according to Italian news sources.  Before leaving the family home, he left a briefcase with €, and a sheet of paper with a numerical sequence, a code which was deciphered by his eldest son, . Aerospace student Filippo told Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera earlier this month: “It was a message Dad left me to decipher, I am sure of it, because he knew I am passionate about mathematical games.” Mr Mannino, a former supermarket manager, is said to have checked the weather forecast for Edinburgh and Aberdeen before leaving Italy. He was described as “tranquil” and “happy” before going missing and left his mobile phone behind, with the recent call history deleted. Mr Mannino, who claims to be unable to speak Italian, has been communicating in basic English. When police in Edinburgh were called to reports of a man taking unwell last month, he was not carrying any ID. Two weeks later officers issued an appeal to help identy a “man with no memory”.  During the public appeal for information, they used the Italian’s tattoos to help identy him. At the time, Constable Lesley Jack said: “This is a very unusual inquiry, as we have a member of the public who has no idea about who he is, where he is from or who we can call on his behalf. “As is standard practice, we have reviewed all relevant missing people and the man does not match the description of anyone currently reported missing. “We hope that, by issuing this detailed description, someone will recognise this male and come forward to assist with our inquiries.” Mr Mannino’s we and eldest child later flew to Edinburgh, but he claimed not to know who they were. He is being assessed at a psychiatric ward in Pisa, where doctors are yet to diagnose his condition.

title: blether too cold for golf so local golf pro took up ice hockey with dundee rockets
story: The winter months usually mean time is sparse for playing rounds of golf.And this certainly was the case many years ago for one golf professional.So much so, that he got involved in a completely dferent sport – playing ice hockey with the Dundee Rockets!Graeme Hume was the professional at Downfield Golf Club from -, and he said: “Regarding playing then with the Rockets, I think I met Tom Stewart when he came to play golf at Downfield with Willie Murray.“Although I used to go to all the Rockets games, I was not involved, just a spectator, and also went to some away games.“Anyway, Tom allowed me to come up some Friday nights for a skate and let me have a go at some of the training exercises they did.“I was not much good I might add but I enjoyed every minute and it kept me fit!”This attracted Press attention at the time, as Graeme continued: “Ron Skelton, who was The Courier golf reporter at the time did a small article about what did golf pros do during the winter months and that was when he got a photo of me at the rink with the Rockets kit on.“This was circa winter , I think.“I never had any thoughts of playing ice hockey.“I just enjoyed watching the games and a bit of travelling with the team on away matches.”Some great names were involved with the Rockets then, as Graeme went on: “Other Rockets names I remember were Mike Mazur , Charlie Kinmond, Peem Lafferty, Joe Guilcher, Sammy McDonnald, Jimmy Penicuik, Mike Ward, Molly Reid, George Reid and Willie Murray.“I also got to know Derek Reillylater in le and played some golf with him – a great centre ice, poacher!“Some of the above are still playing hockey with the Old Timers on a Friday afternoon at Dundee Ice Arena.”Graeme currently lives in the Falkirk area and concluded: “I loved the Downfield club and all the people there.“We had a great junior section at that time.“My good friend Bill Barclay was one of those juniors at that time – and he has just won the Senior Club Championship.”

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: cash raised for upkeep of dundee station piano
story: An all-star charity concert has raised a further £, for the upkeep of the new “people’s piano” at Dundee train station.The gig, held at Clarks on Lindsay Street, brought musicians from across the city together to perform to ensure the instrument’s future maintenance costs are covered.Dundonians had already raised £, to buy the replacement after the original was smashed shortly after its installation.The piano was donated to the new £ million station by local man Dave Patterson in memory of his late we Jean, a former ScotRail employee, who died earlier this year.Performances included acoustic sets by The Collective, Revolver, The Mess Arounds, Abandon, The Interceptors and Julie  Claire from the Funkin’ Idiots.Also playing were the Love Puppets, David Webster, Gavin McGinty, Alice Marra and Colin Reid, George Harris, Kieron Smart and Stephen Knight.Mr Patterson said: “It was a special night and the performances were all fantastic.“Some of the artists performed the song Piano Man at the end for me which was so touching.”The event was organised by Kit Clark, of s pop group Danny Wilson.The cash will be kept in a charitable trust, with any excess being donated to Alzheimer’s Scotland.

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: dundee linked with move for ex ross county and dundee united defender
story: Another former Ross County player could be on Jim McIntyre’s radar.It emerged on Wednesday, Martin Woods has been training with Dundee and could be the new Dens Park boss’ first signing.And now there’s speculation defender Paul Quinn could also join up.Like Woods, Quinn played under Jim up in Dingwall. The -year-old moved to Dundee United last year but his appearances were limited by injury and illness.And he would have to prove his fitness before being given a contract with the Dark Blues.Meanwhile, the matter of who will be the new assistant boss at Dundee could be resolved soon.Billy Dodds is the manager’s preferred choice but as is now clear his arrival would be unpopular with many fans.Others in the frame include Aberdeen coach Barry Robson and possibly even former Dee skipper, and one-time manager, Barry Smith.Whoever gets the nod should be in place for next week’s clash with Celtic.

title: dundee united is perfect platform for striker pavol safranko
story: Robbie Neilson says Dundee United are giving star striker Pavol Safranko the perfect  to show off his ability.The Slovakian international joined the Tangerines on loan while former boss Csaba Laszlo was still in charge to regain the form that saw Aalborg shell out a six-figure sum last summer.The move to Denmark hasn’t worked out but four goals in his last five games during his loan spell at Tannadice has helped new boss Robbie get off to a positive start with a win and a draw in his first two games.And the new United gaffer is delighted he’s got a player like Safranko to lead the line, evenhe accepts the Slovakian is likely to only be a one-season wonder.He said: “I’ve been very impressed with Pavol, very impressed. He’s definitely one of our key players.“He links the game well, has good strength, very good mobility and a good attitude as well – the rest of the players really like him as well which is a big thing.“You need a striker to lead the line for you that can handle the physicality because the game gets like that in Scotland.“Last Saturday there were a few hefty challenges but he stood up to it. I have been impressed, I think he’s a very good player.“He got a good move before but has had a dficult time since.“However, we’ve given him a  to rebuild himself and I think it’s a good window for him to show what he can do.”Neilson has also revealed he’s upped the tempo in training since taking the reins to get the best out of his new squad.He added: “We have just been trying to get the intensity up in training a wee bit.“When I came in, I looked at all the data at what they had done previously and what I felt I would try to implement because I have dferent ideas about what to do.“I just felt we needed to do something a wee bit dferent to try to get a spark in the team and get some enjoyment.“What you want to do when you come in is work them really, really hard to get them as fit as you can as quick as you can. But you also have to realise where their base is so you can minimise injuries.“We have been pretty lucky with that with only Paul Watson getting a wee tweak in his thigh last week.“The base was good, it was fine and I was happy with it but I just wanted to bring more intensity to training to make it shorter and sharper.”

title: dundee united women on the road to the top after league win
story: Dundee United Women are already looking ahead to next season after clinching the Scottish Women’s Football League One title at Tannadice Park after an emphatic victory over Cove Rangers.It was the first time the United girls had played an official match on Tannadice itself and it turned out to be extra special with silverware presented at the end of a - win.Captain Keira Johnstone said: “I am massively proud of the girls and what we have achieved.“It was a big day for us and the team performed brilliantly.“Everyone has worked hard, players and coaches, to gain promotion to the Scottish Women’s Premier League . We can’t wait to get started next season.”Head coach Gavin Beith added: “To finish the season off the way we did was very pleasing and doing this at Tannadice made it such a special day for everyone involved.“On and off the park so many people have worked extremely hard over the years to support the team and it’s a fitting way to cap off a good season.“Playing SWPL football is going to be exciting for us all.”Paul Wilson, the Community Coaching Manager, commented: “I’m delighted. The girls were excellent.#They handled the pressure of playing at Tannadice and rose to the challenge. They pulled together and the crowd of  really got behind them.”The United girls won , drew three and lost one of their  league games with a goal dference of plus .

title: dundee woman living off 8 a week has debt written off thanks to money advice group
story: An estimated £ million of benefits owed to Dundee residents has been clawed back this year thanks to a team of financial advisers.A city-based financial support service has helped  people with their money troubles since January, having identied £m of local people’s debt.Dundee Money Action provides long-term advice, assistance and support to people who are in debt, struggling to heat their homes or trying to save for the future.Among the  people it has helped to take control of their finances is one vulnerable woman who managed to claim £, of backdated benefits payments.Sammy Heenan, financial support officer for the group said: “She had been on the wrong benefits for three years.“It was quite obvious because she hadn’t been working but she wasn’t getting access to things like free dental treatment.“She was living off of £ a week and that was to feed her son, heat the house and look after her pets as well.”Within weeks, the service helped her access £ per week and a payment of more than £, of backdated money that she had been entitled to.All of the woman’s debt was also written off, as the lending was classed as “irresponsible”, due to the woman’s vulnerable status.Sammy said: “We worked with her a lot after she settled and she felt like she had a voice again.“We built up her confidence and encouraged her and now she’s doing absolutely great.”Dave Morris, project manager, said: “We provide support like looking at income expenditure, home energy checks and debt resolution.“We also provide literacy support to help people understand letters they receive.“We deliver everything in a holistic approach.”

title: new midfielder could figure for dundee in celtic clash
story: Boss Jim McIntyre could have more selection options available when his team face champions Celtic at Dens Park on Wednesday.However, he’ll still have at least a couple of men out injured.Full-back Nathan Ralph and centre-half Genseric Kusunga were not ready to face Hearts on Tuesday evening.Both, though, have been back in training this week and that could put them in contention for a place against the Hoops next midweek.Midfielder Martin Woods, who’s been training at Dens this week, could also be handed a contract in time for involvement in the next outing.However, the likes of Paul McGowan and Josh Meekings are expected to remain on the sidelines as they continue their battles to get back fit after y absences.The club are expected to announce McIntyre’s assistant later today.

title: work on track to complete two pedestrian crossings on kingsway
story: The second phase of work to install two new pedestrian crossings on the Kingsway is due to finish on schedule.Workers have been carrying out extensive surfacing improvements on the ide between the eastbound and westbound stretches of the carriageway between Old Glamis Road and Forfar Road.Alterations have been carried out during off-peak hours, with lane closures taking place between .pm-.am to minimise disruption.The latest phase of works has involved metal studs and markings being laid on the road surface, along with footways at the points where the Kingsway meets Graham Street and Mains Loan.A spokeswoman for Dundee City Council confirmed the latest phase of the project was due to be completed by Saturday.It is understood that further works will be required to install the traffic lights themselves along with the systems required to make them work.The local authority’s plans to install the pedestrian-operated Toucan crossings on the Kingsway are part of its wider efforts to encourage the use of sustainable transport.Funded by a grant from the Scottish Government through its Cycling, Walking and Safer Streets scheme, the crossings will link Dundee south of the Kingsway with Caird Park.The carriageway has been viewed by city planners as a “major barrier” for cyclists and pedestrians wanting to travel to the north or south of the city.Fears of disruption caused by the signals have previously been allayed by council officials, who said the lights will operate on an “on-demand” basis rather than on a timed cycle.A date for the next phase of the works is yet to be set and no further comment on the works was available from the council.

title: Ciyt all set to host a spooky spectacular
story: Members of the public have been advised to be wary of an influx of zombies in Inverness this weekend.The living dead are set to visit the Highland capital today and tomorrow as part of the cityrsquos annual Hallowersquoen celebrations.The ZombieNess celebrations will get under way with a "people hunt" tonight, with the zombies due to emerge from the Victorian Market at around pm.That will be followed by a second hunt tomorrow at pm.Organisers are still on the lookout for volunteers who are willing to be transformed into zombies, and all those who are keen to take part are asked to register between pm and .pm tonight or  noon and .pm tomorrow.Both of the hunts are expected to last two hours ndash unless the zombies prove adept at seeking out their prey.A mass zombie dance has been arranged for the immediate aftermath of tonightrsquos event.Participants will be asked to perform to Dead and Gone, a new track by rock group The Dead Daisies.The group are scheduled to headline the first-ever Monstersfest in Inverness on November  and , and the video for their latest track, which already features zombies, has been viewed around one million times on the video-sharing site YouTube.A film showing the Inverness zombies will be shown on both the bandrsquos and Highland Councilrsquos social media channels after the event.After tomorrowrsquos hunt, the focus will switch to Ness Islands, where the Hallowersquoen show will take place.The performance, Nights of the Living Dead, features young performers from across the Highlands, who have also designed many of the scenes in the show.It has been organised by a number of bodies, including Highland Council, Eden Court, Arts in Motion, Limelight Event Services and Fly Agaric.The show invites families to discover what is hiding behind the bushes at the ever-popular Inverness beauty spot.It will begin at .pm tomorrow and runs for approximately two hours, with a second performance scheduled for .pm on Sunday.Councillor Callum Smith, of the Inverness Events and Festivals working group, said: "We are really looking forward to welcoming families to this yearrsquos shows and we cannot wait to see all the children in their wonderful Halloween costumes."Every year it seems like more and more people are dressing up and helping us create something really unforgettable, and we cannot thank them enough for their support."A number of traffic restrictons will be in place as a result of the events, and motorists are asked to park well away from the site to ease congestion:Ness Walk closed northbound between Balleary Lane and Bught Road. Southbound traffic will be maintained.Bught Road closed northbound between Ness Walk and Bught Avenue. Southbound traffic will be maintained.Bught Road closed between Bught Avenue and the Highland Archive Centre. Access for parking will be controlled by the event organiser.Bught Avenue closed to southbound traffic between its junction with Bught Lane and its junction with Bught Road. Northbound traffic will be maintained.Alternative routes are available using Bught Road , Bught Lane, Bught Drive, Bught Avenue, Glenurquhart Road, Bishoprsquos Road, Ness Walk , Balleary Lane and Balleary Road.Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Dilapidated factory site to be turned into homes
story: COUNCILLORS have welcomed news that a derelict factory and sawmill which can be seen by people using the new Holm Mills bridge is soon to be demolished.Tulloch Homesrsquo contractors are set to move in on Monday to begin the demolition of the eyesore which was built in  but has stood empty for many years.Tulloch will be taking it down as well as tidying up this area which was most recently used to store equipment while the bridge, part of the West Link, was being built.Inverness West councillor Alex Graham said he was delighted with the news."These are enormous unsightly buildings," he said. "The site is absolutely hideous and itrsquos in your face when you come off the bridge."Itrsquos a long-standing Inverness eyesore and as a resident who frequently uses the West Link, I very much welcome its removal at the earliest possible date."Irsquom sure thatrsquos a sentiment shared by everyone  in the city."Ness-side councillor Alasdair Christie echoed his council colleaguersquos views"Itrsquos in a very prominent site opposite the new roundabout just off the bridge," he said. "The buildings have been hidden from view for so long, but with the new bridge itrsquos a blight on the landscape."Itrsquos been derelict for years and obviously it becomes a danger because it could attract children on to the site. Itrsquos had industrial uses and I understand Tulloch have plans to build houses there."A Tulloch spokesman said the demolition work on the factory and adjacent buildings would be completed by Christmas."In the summer of  we will be preparing for the first phase of homes to be constructed for our Ness Side development, with the first occupants entering their new homes in the autumn," he said."The first phase will comprise a mix of executive and three and four bedroom homes, with access from Dores Road."The development will make a major contribution towards meeting Highland Councilrsquos target to tackle the cityrsquos housing need."Tulloch Homes have approval to build  homes at Ness Side over the next  to  years, after planning consent was granted by Highland Council last December. The spokesman added: "Ness Side will signicantly replenish our land bank in the city to ensure we can meet local demand for some time to come."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Family raise cash for autism centre
story: An Inverness family has raised hundreds of pounds for a local autism support facility.Danielle McLeishrsquos son Connorwas diagnosed with the condition earlier this year.Since then she has been fundraising with the help of her family and friends to raise money for the Pines Centre at Drummond School, which supported little Connor.Miss McLeish and her daughter Christina Rosetook part in the Unicorn Pageant, supported by clothing firm Rogue Attitude.The family also organised a medium night at the Chieftain Hotel.In total they raised pound., and donated the sum to the centre along with a number of items to be raffled off."Drummond have been raising money for playground equipment as well as the library so part of the money will go towards that," Miss McLeish said."We also donated a few items to them as well for a raffle, which will hopefully raise even more."The textile company I work for sent me a load of throw blankets and things like that so they will go into the raffle as well."Pines will get some raffle prizes as well as the cheque."My mum and my brother came along as well. It was great that they were able to come along hey have been a great support for Connor."I donrsquot knowpeople realise the effect autism has on a family as a whole. Itrsquos good for people to be educated, and itrsquos good for us to be able to help in some small way."Now the family are planning to make their fundraising drive an annual event, and they have already had backing from local businesses.Miss McLeish insisted that the whole family are determined to do their bit to support the organisations which continue to support Connor."We have decided to make our fundraiser an annual thing," she added."The Chieftain Hotel have said we can use theirroom whenever we like for our next event which is brilliant."We definitely want to match what wersquove raised this year, andpossible, make it even bigger and better."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Fans shocked by city folk gig walkout
story: Music lovers at an Inverness folk night were left stunned when two people walked out in the middle of a performance.Hamish MacDonald, the first person to be appointed as Scotlandrsquos national scriever, or writer in the Scots language, was performing a song he had penned about US President Donald Trump at Inverness Acoustic and Folk Clubrsquos second meeting.The less-than-complimentary lyrics prompted two American tourists to leave MacGregorrsquos bar in Academy Street, where the performance was taking place.The folk nightrsquos organiser, Jo de Sylva, said: "As is the way in folk music, Hamishrsquos performance did court controversy. He had written a song about Donald Trump, which was very, very funny."It was his third song out of six, and the main act hadnrsquot even come on at that point."Most of the crowd were really enjoying themselves and getting behind Hamish, but this couple just grabbed their jackets and stormed out."It turned out they were American and they had been offended by the song."Itrsquos a shame because folk music is historically about getting people to talk about these things."Miss de Sylva said other members of the audience were left perplexed by the incident, and insisted that type of song is not unusual in folk clubs."Itrsquos exactly the kind of thing you would expect to hear in a folk club. The music is traditionally left-leaning," she said."You need to understand that when you go to a folk club, not everyone there is going to agree with your views."People were a bit taken aback."I waited until the end of the song and tried to go after them but they had already gone."It was very unexpected."Despite the interruption, the rest of the event ran smoothly, and tickets are already selling fast for the clubrsquos next meeting."Apart from that, the night was amazing," Miss de Sylva added."It was exactly what you want a folk night to be like."It was only the second event we had held but it is going so well."There are only six tickets left for the next event, and they have only just gone on sale."Itrsquos gone way beyond what we expected it would be."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Knitting festival attracts thousands of enthusiasts
story: More than  people flocked to an annual knitting festival in Inverness.The four-day Loch Ness Knit Fest event offered activities and entertainment for lovers of knitting to enjoy, with people travelling from as far afield as New Zealand and Russia.There were  workshops for visitors, along with presentations and entertainment.Loch Ness Knit Fest director, Cecilia Grigor said: "After three years of experience with this event, we have focused on the feedback to continuously improve our offering and itrsquos really been noticed."It was an ambitious and full programme, but we feel that we have been able to provide plenty of iety to participants. Initial feedback has been incredibly positive with people stating Loch Ness Knit Fest  was the best one yet, with a great venue and attention to detail."Overall, a real positive for us has been the sense of community in the textiles and tourism sector, with many businesses and organisations pulling together to showcase Scotlandrsquos rich fibre arts heritage combined with true Highland hospitality."From local farmers, to yarn producers, whisky distilleries, eateries, restaurants and music venues, it has been a real collaborative project and we were delighted to see more businesses are coming on board year after year".Among those in attendance were renowned knitwear designers Christel Seyfarth, Jo Storie and Di Gilpin who took to the main stage with models to show off their garments.The festival also saw more than  donations of clothes and blankets donated to the Special Care Baby Unitat Raigmore Hospital.Stephanie Hoyle from the Highland Guild of Weavers, Spinners and Dyerssaid: "We support and demonstrate at least six-fibre focused events each year and Loch Ness Knit Fest is most definitely a highlight."Our group of volunteers work to inspire people to have a go. From weaving to spinning and felting there are skills we want to pass down the generations and keep alive."Plans are already under way for the festivalrsquos  outing with tickets on sale early next year.Monday  Oct  : PM

title: New city centre homes set to be completed
story: TEN new homes in Inverness city centre for the Highland Housing Alliance are expected to be completed within the next few days.They are part of a -apartment development at Rainingrsquos Close, which is a development that been constructed by Ark Estates Scotland and William Gray builders.The other six homes are expected to be marketed at affordable rents by Highland Council.The alliance has also announced the completion of six homes in Munlochy and five in Drumnadrochit.With funding from the City Region Deal, the developments by the alliance have been made in partnership with the local authority and Albyn Housing Society.Alliance chief executive Gail Matheson said: "We are delighted to be making a further  homes available for mid-market rent that meet high demand for new housing at Drumnadrochit and Munlochy, and regenerating the Rainingrsquos Stairs area in the city of Inverness."The developments have been delivered in collaboration with the Highland Council, Scottish Government and City Region Deal to bring affordable, well designed, high-quality homes to people and families from both within the local area and those wishing toto the region."The alliance has stated the properties will be included in a so-called mid-market initiative which is specically targeted at people working in the region, adding rents will be below current private rental levels for similar properties in the area.Melissa Kirby will be a resident at Rainingrsquos Close."After living in a modern apartment in London, I am absolutely thrilled to move into a new home that brings modern city living to the Highlands," she said. "It is very central with access to everything from restaurants, shopping and travel right on my doorstep."I am really looking forward to meeting my neighbours as well as enjoying the amazing views from my apartment across the city."The alliance currently manages  mid-market properties through schemes to help people become home owners and this figure is set to rise with completion of a -home scheme in Glendoe Terrace, Inverness in early January.For more, visit www.highlandhousingallianceMonday  Oct  : PM

title: Plans are scrapped for city street festival
story: CITY centre retailers hoping for a bumper week during the ninth annual Inverness Street Festival were crushed to hear the curtain has come down on the celebrations because of a funding shortage.The three-day event showcasing fire-juggling, stilt-walking and other top acts is not going ahead this weekend due to "pressures" on the marketing budgets of two of its three funders.Managers at the Inverness Business Improvement Schemeand the Eastgate Centre said a "dficult decision" was taken not to fund it this time around.Bid manager Mike Smith said it was "unfortunate" but times were tough financially and similar street events were being cancelled for the same reason up and down the country.And Jackie Cuddy from the Eastgate Centre said there was "a substantial cost" to running the festival. "Itrsquos tough out there at the moment and therersquos a lot of demand on peoplersquos marketing budgets," she said. "It was not a decision that was taken lightly but all parties concerned felt it best to take a break from it this year."She was not willing to put a figure on the Eastgate Centrersquos annual funding.Mr Smith said the total running costs for rsquos event came to pound,.The cancellation news came as a surprise for some traders at the Victorian Market, where moves are under way to boost footfall.Cafeacute owner Toni Rutherford from The Little Tea Pot said previous events raised the profile of the area."Irsquom shocked to hear itrsquos not going ahead," she said."It was great to see all of the people coming through the market."The festival was expected to run from yesterday to tomorrow.Last yearrsquos event featured  acts including the popular Granny Turismo and Pete Anderson, who climbs and performs on a ft ladder.The acts were expected to perform in the Victorian Market, and in the High Street, Falcon Square and the Eastgate Centre.The festival has also been supported by the Inverness common good fund to boost trade during the quieter months.Last yearrsquos event was described as the biggest and best ever by organisers.Mr Smith said his teamrsquos market research during the festival suggested more than  per cent of those who were in the city centre had turned out for the festival.Victorian Market trader Stephen Hastie from Hastie  Dyce Butchers said he too was disappointed to hear it would not go ahead.He said: "Hopefully it can be resurrected next year and itrsquos not a thing of the past."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Tennis hub plans get council backing
story: Highland Council has moved a step closer to creating a pound. million regional tennis centre despite some strong opposition.Last Thursday, the care, learning and housing committee voted overwhelmingly in favour of proceeding with an applicationto the next funding round on November .The project is backed by Sport Scotland, Tennis Scotland and the Lawn Tennis Association with proposals that would see funding come from a grant of up to pound million from the Transforming Scottish Indoor Tennis Fund .However, this falls short of the total needed and will leave the council and High Le Highland, the charity which provides leisure services across the region, to source a further half a million pounds.Councillor Andrew Jarvie tabled an amendment opposing the move saying he was "annoyed" because he felt the priority should have been replacing "past it" mobile librariesthat would better serve the whole region.Mr Jarvie said: "I just struggle to connect the dots at a time when we struggle to protect the services that we do have ndash how are we then going on and investing in new services  It seems not the right way to do it."He added the "Inverness-centric project" would be of benefit to the "inner Moray Firth area only."Councillor Richard Laird said he was "a little bit peeved" at the lack of detail.He said: "I donrsquot know whether I support proposals for a tennis centre in Inverness until I have seen the business case, how much it would cost to run and how much it would generate. This proposal is back to front."Despite the objections there was enough support within the committee to push the bid forward to the application stage with a future review to be undertaken on the business case.Brigitte Johnson, whose daughter plays tennis, attended the council in support of the move along with five others.She said: "Currently the issue in Highland is that we donrsquot have any indoor facilities, so kids, adults, anyone who wants to get involved have to travel down the A to Stirling or Gleneagles ndash a long way to go for a game of tennis."Ross Lyon , an S pupil at Fortrose Academy and an avid tennis player believes an indoor facility would greatly benefit young people in the north.He said: "Most tournaments in the winter are indoors down south so having indoor courts up here will allow me to improve and also give me a chance to play all year round which means that I wouldnrsquot fall behind others from the central belt."It would help young kids get into the sport who donrsquot want to play in negative one degrees on a sodden Tuesday night."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Work at Stratton is streets ahead
story: A MAJOR new city housing development has taken a signicant step forward with the completion of an upgraded through route.The pound million Stratton development is expected to provide  new homes for Inverness, including  "affordable" ones.The first householders are expected to move in early next year and developers claim the project will deliver pound. million to the Highland economy along with almost  jobs during the construction phase.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael was due to officially open the new Barn Church Road yesterday.The new road includes improved junctions, pavement and cycleways to accommodate the thousands of residents who will eventually live there.Brian Clarke, from Hazledene Inverness which is leading the construction work on the development, said: "Our investment in Barn Church Road, the key spine infrastructure at Stratton, has been one of the most important aspects underpinning the whole development."Work will now begin on the residential, commercial and community buildings."Our plan includes the creation of green spaces, a childrenrsquos play area, footpaths and cycle paths."The town centre will be an open space with mixed retail and office premises, a health centre, community building and church."The provost said: "The new community at Stratton helps to meet several of the targets that we have for the future of Inverness, offering affordable homes, new jobs and local leisure and health facilities."Highland Council is committed to the creation of new opportunities and sustainable communities which will help retain a young and dynamic workforce in the region."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Young Black Isle pilot keen to see the world
story: SHE may have been fascinated by flying since her childhood, but in the end it did not take Black Isle resident Samantha Fraser long to find her own wings ndash taking just two years from starting her private pilotrsquos licence to being one of Scotlandrsquos youngest female commercial pilots.The -year-old, who was born and brought up in Strathnairn and now lives in Munlochy, said: "My passion is travelling and as part of that going to the airport and watching the aircraft. My first taste at the controls of an aircraft was a flying lesson at Dalcross three years ago and after that, I knew that was what I wanted to pursue as a career."It had run through my mind before, but when I looked at the possibility of becoming a professional pilot initially, I wonderedthis was something I could actually do because it did seem to be so male dominated. But thatrsquos changing rapidly. There are a lot more females training to be pilots now, which is good."Miss Fraser, whose father is Duncan Fraser of Inverness family butcher firm Duncan Fraser and Son, began her path to a flying career by taking three months to qualy as a private pilot, preparing her for the  theoretical exams before advancing onto the flying phase of her course.However, she knew from an early stage whose aircraft she would be flying at the end of her training after quickly being talent spotted by easyJet."All the way through, they were monitoring my training and provided I kept up to their standards, I knew I would be offered a job at the end," Samantha said."From what Irsquove heard so far, itrsquos such a great company to work for and Irsquom really happy to become one of their pilots."With progression to captain usually taking five to seven years, she is well on track to become lead pilot of her own aircraft before she is , but first will be a posting to Edinburgh Airport as a first officer."The routes you fly can y. I think the shortest flight from Edinburgh is over to Belfast. Then the longest is out to Paphos in Cyprus and Tenere, and each of those is just short of five hours each way," she said.Yet even the Cyprus run might be short in comparison to some of her future flightsher ambitions go to plan."At some point, I would like to move on to long haul," she said. "I want to see a bit more of the world."Monday  Oct  : PM

title: cup tickets 50 50 split demanded1
story: Aberdeen were today demanding a - split of the tickets for the League Cup Final.The Dons beat Rangers - at Hampden in the semi-final and will face Celtic at the national stadium in the final on Sunday December .For yesterday’s last-four clash, about , members of the Red Army were in attendance, despite the club at one point having an allocation of , tickets.However, it is expected that demand will be greater for the final and a pm kick-off should make travel easier for supporters.Dons manager Derek McInnes hopes they can secure an even split of tickets, but says Aberdeen’s argument is weakened by the semi-final turnout.He said: “Our argument is weakened based on a semi-final.“But a cup final is there for people to enjoy and we’ve always brought plenty to a cup final.“Our semi-final crowd has normally been as it was yesterday, regardless of the opposition. To get almost , fans down on a Sunday is still not bad shooting – and that’s the way it’s always been for our club.“For cup finals, we’re looking for a lot more and I’m surewe get a - split there will be plenty of people wanting to see Aberdeen competing in a cup final.”

title: 5500 year old north east artefact to go on display at stonehenge
story: A north-east artefact thought to be around , years old is to be part of an exhibition celebrating Stonehenge.A carved stone ball which originated in Old Deer is now featuring in the showcase entitled Making Connections: Stonehenge in its Prehistoric World at the Stonehenge Visitors Centre.The ball, made from iron-rich quartzite, is thought to be from the late Neolithic period, also known as the New Stone Age.The north-east artefact forms part of the exhibition, curated in partnership with The British Museum, which will run until April  next year.Making Connections aims to tell the story of changing prehistoric connections through precious objects of stone, chalk, gold and bronze.Experimental archaeologist James Dilley was tasked with attempting to replicate the stone ball in an online video.An experienced craftsman and PhD student, the work took James weeks to complete.He said: “I specialise in prehistoric technology, and as a result I know the north-east of Scotland quite well. The work took weeks and weeks – I used tools a Neolithic craftsperson would have used.“I work with flint a lot and so I had some experience – the striking and grinding uses a lot of hand-eye co-ordination – however it did take a lot of trial and error.”Though the exact purpose of the stone ball is not known, it is thought they may have been ceremonial objects exchanged between communities.Hundreds of these carved stone balls were made and used between  and  BC.James added: “The ball was acquired by the British Museum in . We aren’t sure exactly where it came from – we know it was presented to the public in Edinburgh in  and we think it may have been discovered in a cairn but that hasn’t been proven.“Aberdeenshire is pretty much the ‘heart’ of where these Neolithic stone balls have been discovered – there are several in the Discovery Centre in Mintlaw.”

title: apprentice style competition to raise money for aberdeen charity
story: Groups and organisations in the north-east are being urged to sign up to an Apprentice-style fundraising challenge.Called Venture, the campaign will see teams gted £ by their employers, with the aim of turning it into more cash in eight weeks.Money raised will go towards children’s charity Charlie House to support plans for a specialist purpose-built support centre to be built in the grounds of Woodend Hospital.Teams are currently being sought to take part in Venture, which is open to groups of four to six, made up of anyone over the age of .Judged by entrepreneur Bob Keiller, each team will be invited to an awards ceremony at Ardoe House Hotel on March , where teams will receive accolades such as most supportive team lead, most innovative fundraising idea, greatest team spirit and best business plan.The winning team will be crowned Charlie House Venture  champions, and will also be gted tickets to Bob Keiller’s Effective Business Storytelling workshop, which is valued at £, per person.Susan Crighton, director of fundraising for Charlie House, said: “Our dream is to have a purpose-built specialist centre here in Aberdeen to provide planned and emergency short breaks, palliative and end-of-le care for children.“Venture will play a vital role in this, as all funds raised will go towards building this facility.”Campbell Urquhart, co-organiser of Venture , said: “As part of the Venture  judging , we are inviting teams to get creative – there’s no limit to what you can do to raise funds, as long as it’s safe and legal!“It really is a great team challenge to get combined minds working together for the best outcome.”All entries for Venture must be received by Charlie House by December .To enter a team, contact fundraise@charliehouse.org.uk or call  .

title: incredible aberdeen slimmer reaches semi finals after losing more than 10 stone
story: A north-east woman has reached the semi-finals of a national slimming competition.Julie Farquhar, from Oldmeldrum, was one of the women to reach the semi-finals of Slimming World’s Woman of the Year  competition after she lost st .lb.She was one of  to make it to that stage.The -year-old said: “Before I found Slimming World, everything just felt like such a struggle.“Simple tasks would become massive chores because I’d get out of breath so easily, and having so much weight to lose just felt like such a struggle.”As a well done for getting so far and losing so much weight, she met Hollyoaks actor Jamie Lomas, who congratulated her on her achievement.He said: “She’s done amazingly well to change her le around like she has.“She seems so full of confidence now and that’s really great to see.”

title: new drive to boost seafood trade to us
story: Members of the fishing industry will meet the US ambassador today to discuss trade opportunities.Representatives of the fish catching and processing sectors, along with the salmon industry, will take part in a meeting in London chaired by the US ambassador to the UK Woody Johnson.Mr Johnson met senior seafood industry players during a visit to the new Peterhead Fish Market in August, where he said he was impressed with the quality of produce.On histo the capital, he invited representatives to the meeting, including from the Peterhead Port Authority, Lunar Fishing Company and the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation .SFF chief executive Bertie Armstrong said the fishing industry stands on the “cusp of a new era”.He added: “We are extremely grateful to the ambassador for calling this round table.“He was genuinely enthused by what he saw on his visit to Peterhead and is taking a close personal interest in supporting our endeavours.”The Scottish Seafood Association, Scottish Pelagic Processors’ Association and the Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation were also expected to attend today’s gathering.

title: north east bar applies for permission to open early on sundays
story: A north-east bar has applied to a local authority to y its licence.Quoiters Bar in Newtonhill has submitted an application to Aberdeenshire Council which,approved, could allow it to sell alcohol earlier on a Sunday.The Skateraw Road pub currently opens to sales at the premises from .pm but is looking to get this changed to am.Included in the application is the proposal of selling teas, coffees and light snacks out with the normal licenced hours.The application has come from  Bars Limited, with members of the public able to voice their opinion on the proposal by writing to Aberdeenshire Council.A deadline on views from residents has been set for November .More information for residents about giving comments on licencing matters can be found online on www.aberdeenshire.gov.uk licensing

title: cove lose out to able junior side
story: Cove Rangers striker Mitch Megginson says they must learn to become more “streetwise” after losing - to Junior side Auchinleck Talbot in the Scottish Cup.The Highland League champions were denied a visit to Fraserburgh in the third round when they were out-muscled, as opposed to out-played, by their Ayrshire hosts at Beechwood Park.Megginson, who scored Cove’s goal from a second-half penalty, felt the match was similar to last season’s promotion play-off, which they lost - after failing to handle the aggressive approach of League Two opponents Cowdenbeath down at Central Park.The former Aberdeen player believes it’s vital they find ways of showing they can fight as well as play football in case they make the play-offs again at the end of this season.Megginson said: “These are the sort of games we need to winwe ever want to compete at higher levels.“The way we lost to Auchinleck was almost a copy of what happened to us down at Cowdenbeath. They didn’t play better football than us, they were just more aggressive and didn’t care how they went about knocking us out of our stride.“We are going to have to show we can stand up for ourselves betterthat ever happens again. I include myself in that.“That’s twice it has happened to us in the space of a few months, so we really should have known what to expect and handled it better.“I’ve had even more experience of it than some of the other lads because I’ve played in a good few matches like those last two when I was in the SPFL.“No matter the level, the teams down south just seem to be more streetwise than we are at times.“If we are lucky enough to make the play-offs again we are going to have to show lessons have been finally learnedwe want to avoid losing again.”Cove had fallen behind to a first-half strike by Stephen Wilson before Megginson’s st goal of the season brought them level.Slack defending then saw the Scottish Junior Cup holders regain the lead through Calvin Kemp midway through the second period.Despite never being at their very best, Cove almost snatched a last-gasp equaliser when a Blair Yule shot rebounded to safety off one of the Talbot posts, with the home keeper well beaten.Referee Chris Fordyce also brushed aside two late penalty claims by Cove, one of them for a tug on substitute Jordan McRae as he prepared to pull the trigger.

title: mcinally pleased with blue toons resilience
story: Peterhead boss Jim McInally hailed the resilience shown by his players in their - win against Clyde.The Blue Toon were ahead through Scott Brown in the first half at Broadwood. But after the break they had Mick Dunlop sent off.Things were evened up soon after when Tom Lang was red carded for the Bully Wee. Sub Derek Lyle made it - to the Buchan side before Jason Brown’s own goal gave Clyde hope.Lyle got his second for Peterhead to secure the points which keep them second in League Two just two points behind leaders Edinburgh City.McInally said: “Some people maybe thought we would slip up. But I have to say it’s now very hard for me to pick a team.“On Saturday on the bench we had Derek Lyle, Ryan Dow, Simon Ferry, Cammy Eadie and Callum Home. We don’t have the biggest squad.“But there is quality there and that is the message we’ve sent out that we can cope with stuff.“When Mick got sent off we dealt with it – a lot of players stepped up to the plate.“Scott Brown was terric, Willie Gibson came on to a good game and we defended well.“With Edinburgh City doing so well we’re going under the radar which is quite good.“We’ve won six in a row and all we can do is keep it going and hope Edinburgh slip up.“The resilience we’ve got does please me and I see players like Derek Lyle who might think he should be starting.“But he took it on the chin and then went on and scored two goals for us and it gives me a good headache.”McInally was pleased with the impact his subs made following Dunlop’s red card.He added: “I thought in the first half we were comfortable without playing well.“Clyde are a strong side and it’s not easy to go to these articial pitches and play well, but we coped with everything well.“Just before half-time they claimed for a penalty, but I also felt we should have had one when Rory McAllister was pushed going for a header.“We didn’t start the second half well and they came at us for the first  minutes.“When Mick Dunlop got sent off I was away to make two changes, so that forced me into reshuffling it.“Ryan Dow, Derek Lyle and Cammy Eadie came on for us after Mick’s sending off and they were fantastic.“We needed fresh legs because I knew it would be a hard game for us with  men, but when they went down to  men it levelled it up. It’s a brilliant result to go down there and win.”Peterhead’s opener came on  minutes when Scott BROWN drove forward and lashed home a shot from  yards.On  minutes Dunlop was given a straight red card by ref Gavin Ross after a - challenge.Five minutes later Clyde’s Lang was dismissed after picking up a second yellow card.On  minutes LYLE made it -, curling home after Ryan Dow and Scott Brown combined to set him up.Clyde had hope five minutes later when Jason BROWN turned Karim Belmokhtar’s cross into his own net, but on  minutes LYLE made it - when he fired home from the edge of the box.

title: my lynx are back refreshed
story: An early-season break in fixtures has recharged the Aberdeen Lynx, according to head coach Owen Reynolds.The Lynx have had a dismal time in the inaugural Scottish National League Eastern Conference, in which they have one game left, losing six of seven so far.A shortened pre-season saw the Granite City men start the campaign undercooked but, without a match the last two weeks, Reynolds, pictured, has been able get his team thinking positively again.He said: “We’ve taken advantage of the break in our fixtures and had a bit of fun in training over the last few weeks.“It’s been back to serious business this week, though, in preparation for tomorrow’s tie against Kilmarnock Thunder in the Scottish Cup.“It’s been a draining start to the season both physically and mentally, but we’ve had a chance to recharge so it’ll be good to get going again this weekend.“Kilmarnock have a small ice pad which brings its own set of challenges – games can change pretty quickly when there’s not much room to move and shorter distances to cover.“They also have a lot of young, talented players so we won’t be taking anything for granted.“Regardless of how close our results have been at the start of the season, we’re on a losing streak so will be looking to put an end to it on Saturday.“We also see theof Ross McIntosh this weekend, who missed the start of the season due to working overseas.“Ross is always a threat up front so hisis a welcome boost to the squad.”
