title: easyjet-moving-fast-in-developing-electric-planes
story: Chief executive Johan Lundgren claimed electric flying is ldquobecoming a reality and he can foresee a future that is ldquonot exclusively dependent on jet fuel.The Luton-based carrier is in a partnership with US-based manufacturer Wright Electric to build battery-propelled aircraft for flights of less than two hours by .Wright Electric has applied for a patent on a motor for an electric airliner.It already has a two-seater electric plane and plans to begin flying a nine-seater next year.EasyJet believes the progress means an all-electric commercial passenger jet capable of flying passengers across its European network is ldquoin sight.London-Amsterdam has a strong demand for daytrips and could be ldquoan ideal route for the technology to be used.Mr Lundgren said: ldquoLooking forward, the technological advancements in electric flying are truly exciting and it is moving fast.ldquoFrom the two-seater aircraft, which is already flying, to the nine-seater which will fly next year, electric flying is becoming a reality and we can now foresee a future that is not exclusively dependent on jet fuel.Wright Electric predicts electric planes will be up to % quieter and % cheaper for airlines to buy and operate, compared with traditional aircraft.The company is focused on improving batteries and making the aircraft frame as efficient as possible for use with electric motors.Conventional short-haul aircraft have one large jet engine underneath each wing, but electric planes would have several smaller motors.Its chief executive Jeffrey Engler said: ldquoWe are excited about what the next year holds. EasyJet has been a fantastic partner and we look forward to helping introduce low-emissions, low-noise aviation, to Europe.

title: hammond-tells-mps-era-of-austerity-finally-coming-to-an-end
story: In his last scheduled Budget before Brexit, Mr Hammond promised his proposals would pave the way for a ldquobrighter future.His comments come after Prime Minister Theresa May promised she was ending years of austerity.ldquoThe era of austerity is finally coming to an end, Mr Hammond told MPs.Downing Street has insisted that the Budgetrsquos spending announcements are fully funded, regardless of whether the UK secures a Brexit deal, in what has been viewed as a rebuke to the Chancellor.Mr Hammond warned at the weekend that his economic plans depend on a successful outcome to the Brexit negotiations with Brussels.In the event of a no-deal break with the EU, he said he would be forced to tear them up and institute an emergency budget to set the economy on a ldquonew direction.But Theresa Mayrsquos official spokesman insisted that the Chancellor was indicating that he was ready to use his ldquofiscal firepower to shore up the economythe UK withdraws without a deal.In his Budget statement, Mr Hammond said he was setting aside an extra pound million for Brexit preparations, adding that ldquo the economic or fiscal outlook changes materially in-year I reserve the right to upgrade the Spring Statement to a full Fiscal Event.Speaking in the Commons Mr Hammond said he was promising a ldquoBudget for hard-working families and told MPs ldquowe have reached a defining moment on this long, hard journey after repairing the damage to the public finances caused by the financial crash.

title: investigation-scotlands-firms-argentinas-bribes-and-uzbekistans-dirty-cotton
story: Two of this countryrsquos limited partnerships were allegedly used to funnel kickbacks in the latest twist in a corruption ldquomega scandal ripping through Latin America.Prosecutors say one of the best-connected lobbyists in Buenos Aires used the anonymously-owned Scottish firms ndash SLPs ndash to take cash from the Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht infor state contracts.The case comes as a Herald on Sunday investigation published today reveals anonymous SLPs and similar English structures were used to make hundreds of millions of dollars of untraceable ldquoforeign investment in Uzbekistan.Anti-corruption and human rights campaigners in the Central Asian nation ndash still one of the least open societies in the world ndash are demanding to know where the money comes from. They are particularly concerned over secretive buy-ups of the nationrsquos cotton industry, with its record of slavery and environmental damage.Cotton workers in UzbekistanConcerns over both bribery in Latin America and opaque investments in the former Soviet Union prompted Britainrsquos big business lobby to issue a warning about SLPs.Tracy Black, Scotland director of the CBI, said: ldquoThese reports are concerning because they pose a risk to the hard-won reputation of Scottish business.ldquoWe want Scottish firms to feel confident about pitching for international projects and exporting to global markets.ldquoThis comes at a time when business is working tirelessly in partnership with the government to attract top talent and much needed investment.Over the last three years The Herald and former Sunday Herald have published scores of stories about the abuse of SLPs. These include allegations that Odebrecht ndash whose officials admit paying bribes of at least m across the Spanish and Portuguese-speaking world, used SLPs and other British corporate entities to suborn officials and politicians.:Peru leader accused of taking bribes through company based at Scots law firmThe UK Government ndash which is responsible for Scots corporate law ndash is currently mulling new reforms to the structures under pressure from opposition and backbench MPs, such as the SNPrsquos Alison Thewliss.British officials ndash especially since the attempted murders in Salisbury ndash are particularly concerned about the abuse of SLPs in Russia.UK firms, including SLPs and Scottish limited companies, were are the centre of the  billion Russian Laundromat, one of the biggest and most elaborate money-laundering schemes ever uncovered.The CBIrsquos concerns echo those of Scottish politicians, who have long warned of a threat to the countryrsquos corporate reputation from SLPs involved in global fraud and money laundering.In some major markets the words ldquoScottish firm has come to have the same kind of image as ldquoSwiss bank account.:How Britain enables routine, everyday corruption and fraud in the ex-USSRResearcher Ben Cowdock of anti-corruption group Transparency International said: ldquoIt is now well established that SLPs have been a money-laundering vehicle of choice for corrupt iniduals around the world. Controlled by anonymous offshore companies, they have proven to be effective in funnelling bribes to politicians and allowing corrupt elites to gain control of key industrial assets.ldquoTheir continued use in high corruption risk jurisdictions should raise red flags to law enforcement agencies in the UK and abroad.Cowdock added: ldquoIt is clear that money launderers and corrupt iniduals have sought to exploit the UKrsquos ease of doing business for criminal ends ... As the tally of crimes committed with UK companies mounts, the cost of inertia becomes increasingly clear.The SLPs in the Argentinian case have not named their owners under rules Cowdock cites. Nor have most of the SLPs and other firms making opaque investments in Uzbekistan. No business has been prosecuted for failure to comply with transparency laws.The UK Government is expected to unveil reforms before Christmas.Long Read: The Scottish shop at the Centre of the World Main Street, DouglasOn the long, narrow drag of a Scottish mining village, opposite The Countryside Inn and just a step or two from The Mane Attraction hairdressers, there is a little shop, a former draperrsquos.Number  Main Street looks like a house a child would draw: a square sandstone terrace with a wooden front door flanked by hanging baskets and two rectangular windows, each with a wooden owl perched on its sill.This is real Douglas, South Lanarkshire. But there is also a fake Douglas, a counterfeit  Main Street, one that only exists online: the HQ, among other things, of a global corporation with offices in New York, Los Angeles, Tokyo, Copenhagen and beyond.This particular make-believe version of the draperrsquos shop has a two-storey glass and steel atrium, huge open-planned rooms and an army of hipster staff in designer glasses.It is, at least according to its own website, the Londonoffice of Falcon Business Services, an international ldquocreative advertising agency working for blue-chip clients like Starbucks, HM, Boeing, Cisco and even disgraced mogul Harvey Weinsteinrsquos now bankrupt movie-making concern.Falconrsquos internet offering may look slick ndashauthentic, it would be by far the biggest and most successful business in Scotlandrsquos under-pressure advertising sector ndash but the sitersquos gobbledygook English gives its fakery away.ldquoWe appreciate every culture, we are consist from many dferent culture from many country around the worlds, the agency boasts on its site about its ldquoLondon HQ in Douglas. ldquoThis place very big and cozy, this is our main office consist of large amount of employee across the world.How Falcon portrays its HQ, screen grab of its websiteBack at the real  Main Street, Lilli Clark bursts out laughing when she hears how Falcon describes her surroundings. Clark, with friend Sally Kerr, runs a small book-keeping practice at the old shop, including a ldquovirtual office where a Falcon Business Services is, indeed, registered.The pair find themselves on the edge of the surreal world of Scotlandrsquos notorious ldquotax haven firms: of ghost companies of here-today, gone-tomorrow anonymously owned corporate entities. That is because their address is the registered HQ of thousands of businesses, many created as global criminals exploit Britainrsquos lax and barely policed corporate transparency laws.Most are Scottish limited partnerships or SLPs, a kind of shell firm which anti-corruption campaign Transparency International describes as ldquoa vehicle of choice for money-laundering.Falcon is an SLP. There is no way of knowing who owns the business, how much money it turns over or evenit has anything to do with the website in its name.This, for Clark, is not funny. Because it means her address does not just feature on shlocky websites: it also stars in some of the worldrsquos biggest crime stories.Two years ago The Herald revealed ldquonumber  was the official home of firms at the centre of a major Ukrainian investigation in to allegedly corrupt side-payments on an arms export to the Middle East. Since then Douglas shell firms have rarely been out of the news.Clark stresses she knows nothing about any of the firms using her address. ldquoWe have no control over them whatsoever, she explains. ldquoWe want to get rid of them but we canrsquot.She sighs as she hears the latest on Douglas SLPs. That is because they number among a series of UK shell firms ndash with no identiable real world connection to Britain ndash which The Herald on Sunday has identied as being behind supposedly multi-million-dollar investments in the tyrannical Central Asian state of Uzbekistan.Just one SLP, called Quality Trade Supplies or QTS, is building a steel mill in the Uzbek capital, Tashkent, for just over  million euros. This ldquoBritish investment was announced by Uzbekistanrsquos president, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, with an official visit to its -hectare site, which, unlike Falconrsquos global HQ, is very real.Presidential press releaseTwo decades after the closure of Ravenscraig, a Scottish company is again investing in steel, albeit overseas. Or is it The Herald on Sunday has made multiple attempts to contact QTS, whose website says it has a representative office in Kazakhstan, as well as its official home at  Main Street, Douglas. We wanted to ask QTS who its owner was. The firm has failed to comply with new UK rules under which last year it should have named any ultimate beneficiary or PSC ndash a ldquoperson of signicant control.The firmrsquos website says the Tashkent Metallurgical Plant is a ldquostate project ndash while the state itself says it is a QTS project. The stated investment is one of the biggest carried out by a Scottish enterprise overseas in recent years.QTS on its site also said it was also building a km railway line with  stops across Kazakhstan, part of a major drive to improve transport links between China and Europe. That job, it said, would involve  construction workers. Again, this would be a nearly unprecedented venture for a Scottish firm.Uzbeks also have questions about who owns QTS. One prominent former Soviet oligarch has been named locally as being behind the firm. A London public relations firm acting on his behalf has denied any connection.Mirziyoyev has also given his official blessing ndash and visit ndash to another major ldquoBritish investment from a Douglas firm, a m cement factory in the underdeveloped western Uzbek region of Karakalpakstan.Shavkat MirziyoyevUzbekistanrsquos Ministry of Economy formally lists ldquoforeign investments in infrastructure or industry every year. These include a roll-call of SLPs with either opaque ownership or PSCs filed in the name of untraceable Uzbeks. At least five other Douglas SLPs are named in press reports or official bulletins as recent investors. None have transparent ownership or any real-world links to Lanarkshire.Uzbek authorities have also named a series of English and Welsh shell firms, mostly limited liability partnerships or LLPs, as ldquoforeign investors.Take Fortalia Consult, a now struck-off LLP. It put up m for a .m factory making washing machines, fridges and cookers. The plant, partly funded by the state National Bank of Uzbekistan, employed hundreds. LLPs have to provide more information on Britainrsquos corporate registry, including accounts. Fortalia, in its last year of existence, , made an operating profit of pound on a turnover of just over pound,. A company investing millions in a white appliances factory made a profit of under a tenner. It did, however, file a PSC. She was Uzbek.Official bulletins, government press releases and state-controlled media reports suggest SLPs and LLPs whose owners are either Uzbeks or unknown have made declared ldquoforeign direct investments of well over poundm in recent years.Other investments officially made by SLPs and LLPs are in real-world factories making everything from spinning equipment to probiotic dairy produce.One of the businesses investing in a major new business district, Tashkent City, is an Edinburgh SLP called Corso Solutions. Corso was created last year but has failed to comply with new rules under which it was supposed to say who its owner is. Fines for failure to comply are pound a day. None has ever been levied.TashkentHuman rights campaigners ndash Uzbek and international ndash have grave concerns about this. They want to know who is buying up chunks of the countryrsquos economy. They are especially concerned about equity and other investments in cotton, the nationrsquos biggest industry.Uzbekistan is currently reforming its cotton farms, which have a record of forced labour ndash slavery, effectively ndash and environmental abuses which have led to the near-disappearance of one of the worldrsquos biggest lakes, the Aral Sea. But reforms are only just beginning. They include partial privatisations that have seen SLPs and English shell firms buy stakes in both processing and picking enterprises.CottonTwo, Trontex of Stirling and Gratum Trading of Edinburgh, received import tax breaks under a Mirziyoyev decree. Both firms, like QTS, have filed at Companies House saying they have not yet attempted to identy a PSC.The Herald on Sunday has written to both Mirziyoyevrsquos press office in Tashkent and the Uzbek Embassy in London. We askedthe president knew who the beneficiaries of his tax breaks were. There was no reply. We also wrote askinghe was concerned that major ldquoforeign investors were failing to reveal who they were. Again, there was no reply.This worries Umida Niyazova. She is a journalist and campaigner who was jailed under Mirziyoyevrsquos predecessor, the authoritarian Islam Karimov. Now based in Berlin, she leads the Uzbek-German Forum for Human Rights .She says: ldquoThe cotton sector in Uzbekistan is entirely under the control of the state which sets the price of cotton and is the sole beneficiary of revenue from sales on the international market."Umida NiyazovaShe adds: ldquoUGF has been monitoring and reporting on state-organised forced labour in Uzbekistanrsquos cotton sector for over eight years. We can confirm that, despite some changes, mass mobilization of forced labour and extortion from organisations and employees to pay for cotton pickers is again ongoing during this yearrsquos cotton harvest, despite Mirziyoyevrsquos public commitments to eradicate it.ldquoFor decades, the production of cotton has been underpinned by a system ... in which Uzbekistanrsquos citizens are forcibly mobilised to pick cotton. This is a state-operated system of forced labour, in which the Uzbek government imposes regional cotton production quotas which are, in turn, allocated by regional officials to their sub-districts.ldquoRegional and district officials are responsible for meeting these quotas under threat of penalty.ldquoWe have observed a proleration of Uzbek entities registered as limited partnerships in Scotland and England, including a number of companies with direct ties to the cotton industry.ldquoWe are interested to know why these companies, in receipt of large swathes of foreign direct investment, want to register in Scotland. Why do these companies not disclose their ownership  Given that hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign direct investment are flowing into the country at this time, the UK government must ensure these companies are not a vehicle for money laundering.ldquoUzbekistanrsquos cotton sector has already disrupted the lives of millions. It would be criminalthey were to be robbed of revenue which should ultimately benefit the Uzbek people.Abandoned ships on the dried-out Aral SeaUzbek sources stress they have no evidence SLPs or LLPs investing in cotton or other industries are responsible for human rights abuses. Nor do they have evidence any nominally UK registered firms are fronts for government officials or others who wish to conceal their identities. They just want to know who is behind investment. They have reason to be concerned. SLPs have been widely abused where in the former Soviet Union, including as part of multi-billion-dollar schemes to launder money out of Russia, Ukraine and Azerbaijan.At last count, some  Uzbeks were named as the PSCs of SLPs. But multiple investigations reveal closer links. A nephew of former leader Islam Karimov in  was named as the effective controller of SLPs involved in a dispute over the ownership of hotels in Riga which culminated in an attempted gangland-style hit.Last year an international journalistic investigation alleged that Karimovrsquos youngest daughter, Lola, and her husband used three SLPs ndash two of which, Five Star Star Technology Support and Greenhall Management, are based in Douglas ndash as part of complex offshore scheme. None of the SLPs has named a PSC.Lola Karimova, from Getty ImagesMs Karimova is a multi-millionaire who last year launched her own fragrance at a party at the Cannes Film Festival attended by Juliette Binoche, Catherine Deneuve, Kristin Scott Thomas and Pamela Anderson.She denies detailed allegations of tax avoidance set out by journalists at a group called The Black Sea.This month Britainrsquos Serious Fraud Office announced it had begun a proceeds of crime investigation against Ms Karimovarsquos estranged elder sister, Gulnara, once touted as a replacement for her father.She is in prison near Tashkent on embezzlement charges, which she denies. British authorities are understood to be seeking to confiscate London properties linked to her and an associate. Swiss authorities have already seized some m in assets.Gulnara Karimova, from Getty ImagesMeanwhile, as The Herald revealed this year, The United Nations Development Programme has blacklisted five SLPs amid concerns over international aid fraud in Uzbekistan. The sanctions are against SLPs called Special Alliance Partnership, Investment Affairs, Trident Asia and Five Star Commercial Services.They are all registered either at  Main Street, or a flat in Edinburghrsquos Montgomery Street, number .The owners of this property, like Clark and Kerr, once ran a virtual office business. They too stress they have no control over the entities registered at what is their home. They also have tried and failed to get SLPs de-registered.Some SLPs have been transferred from Montgomery Street to Douglas. They include Tashkent steel mill builder QTS, whose website still has a map showing its Edinburgh HQ.Montgomery Street, EdinburghThe Montgomery Street flat has been the base for SLPs which played a key role in the -billion Russian Laundromat, one of the biggest and most elaborate money-laundering schemes ever uncovered.:A Baltic bank, a Belarussian bribe and a British embarrassmentNow government investigators in Argentina allege two SLPs using the address were used as part of one of the worldrsquos biggest bribery scandals.Earlier this year The Herald revealed the role played by Scottish shell firms in complex offshore structures used by a construction giant called Odebrecht to pay kickbacks to officials and politicians across Latin America and beyond. The so-called ldquomega scandal ndash nearly bn was paid out, Odebrecht admits ndash has rocked the western hemisphere and led to prosecutions against senior officials in multiple jurisdictions.A former president of Peru, who denies using an SLP based at a Glasgow law firm to take money infor a highway contract, is among those facing prosecution. A senior state oil official close to the outgoing president of Mexico also dismisses reports he took money from the construction firm through SLPs.In Argentina, government anti-corruption investigators have focused on a prominent entrepreneur called Jorge Rodriacuteguez, though he usually goes by the nickname ldquoCorcho, or ldquoCork.In a ldquobox office celebrity court case, Rodriacuteguez is accused of taking in bribes from Odebrecht, which was among companies bidding to build a metro line. He denies any wrongdoing.Corcho Rodriacuteguez, from YouTubeAn Argentinian government report suggests money was transferred the tax haven bank accounts of two SLPs to Uruguay. From there, investigators allege, Rodriacuteguez used his fleet of private plans to fly money in cash across the River Plate to a small airfield near Buenos Aires. Figures of up to m have been cited.The two SLPs named in official papers are Latin Financial and Capital Investment Enterprises, both of which were created and dissolved without ever filing any meaningful paperwork. Rodriacuteguez says he has no connection with the two Scottish firms. His Uruguayan accountants, in testimony, say they were his.The case continues. Rodriacuteguez ndash often described as a lobbyist ndash was part of a politically-linked Buenos Aires jetset often seen in the Uruguayan resort of Punto del Este.His we, Veroacutenica Lozano, hosts a chat show on Argentinian TV. His ex, former s film star Susana Gimeacutenez, has an even bigger rival programme and her own monthly glossy magazine, on whose cover she always features.Susana GimeacutenezAn Odebrecht official in Brazil, Marcio Faria do Bentos, earlier this year said there had been a smooth flow of illicit payments to Argentina until former president Neacutestor Kirchner died in  while his we, Cristina, ran Argentina. The system, Faria said, started ldquoticking smoothly again after he was contacted by Rodriacuteguez.Anti-corruption campaigners are more than aware of the absurdity of linking the fleshpots of Punta del Este or Cannes with Montgomery Street flat, with a derelict phone box in its front garden, or a Lanarkshire draperrsquos shop.The Buenos Aires metroBut Scotland ndash and the UK ndash is part of a world-wide machine for washing dirty money. Our SLPs and our LLPs are like the Swiss banks of old, the means to hide illicit wealth with a veil of British respectability.Graham Barrow, UK-based money-laundering expert, has been slowly but surely unpicking and exposing the system in a series of detailed essays. The Uzbek and Argentinian cases, he says, ldquohighlight yet again that this is a global problemwhich can only be solved by a global effort.But he adds: ldquoThe UK can make a huge contribution by better regulating these entities so that they donrsquot keep cropping up in far flung corners of the world for all the wrong reasons. The British Government is mulling reforms.Punta del Este, UruguayMeanwhile, back in the through-the-looking class world of fake Douglas, ldquoScottland, Falcon Business Services is hiring creatives. On offer, among other benefits, are ldquofree snacks. ldquoJoin our awesome and fantastic team, its site claims in its trademark broken English, ldquoWe offers you a bright shine of your next career level. The Herald on Sunday tried to contact Falcon. All its contact details were bogus, its telephone was , its fax . Britain has still to get the number of its fake firms.So what are SLPs SCOTTISH Limited Partnerships, to give them their proper name, were once just a means for farmers to share fields.Then some lawyers figured out such structures made tax-efficient vehicles for managing equity funds. And others realised they were also enticing for people who want to avoid more than just tax.Writer Oliver Bullough has explored the murky world of international offshore finance ndash and its effect on some of the planetrsquos poorest nations ndash for his book Moneyland. He has long watched SLPs being abused.ldquoSLPs and shell structures like them are absolutely crucial to anyone who has wealth to hide, he explains. ldquoWithout them, it would be impossible for crooks and thieves ndash whether theyrsquore rulers of former Soviet states, or leaders of drugs cartels ndash to move their wealth out of the shadows and into the legitimate economy."Bulloughs bookHe adds: ldquoSLPs are useful to crooks because, unlike limited partnerships where in the UK, they have legal personality and thus can own bank accounts and other assets, enter into contracts, and take on debt. If the SLPrsquos partners are offshore companies, then their ownership is completely opaque.ldquoThe great advantage of Britain as a place to register a company is that the company looks legitimate, because itrsquos British, but really is not. Our money-laundering regime is so lax, and Companies House doesnrsquot check the accuracy of any information supplied to it. This is why British structures are almost iniably found in the biggest financial scandals.The abuse of SLPs, Bullough stresses, is not a victimless crime. ldquoMore than a trillion dollars a year is stolen from the worldrsquos poorest countries, devastating their economies and spreading misery and destitution, he says. ldquoThat would not be possible without shell structures like SLPs, and itrsquos imperative the UK Government acts to reform them to they can no longer be misused in this way.A map of just some of the SLP scandals in recent yearsA spokesman for the Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said: "The UK is leading the global fight against money laundering. "Changes to the law last year have increased the transparency of these financial arrangements, reducing the likelihood of them being used for illegal purposes.ldquoWe carefully developed our recent reforms to further prevent these crimes without harming the legitimate businesses and pensions that invest through limited partnerships.Registrations of SLPs have fallen in the last year after new PSC reguilations were introduced and, crucially, banks in Latvia started refusing to handle their accounts.Comment: Alison Thewliss on why SLP reform cannot waitMore than three months have passed since the UK Government closed its consultation on the reform of limited partnerships, and despite calls for recommendations to be published, nothing has been forthcoming.Today we see yet more evidence linking limited partnerships to opprobrious behaviour abroad this time with regards cotton production in Uzbekistan.Agencies such as Amnesty International, and the Uzbek-German Forum for Human Rights, have gone to great s to expose the coercive and manipulative nature of this industry.Alison ThewlissThe purported involvement of financial vehicles registered in the UK ndash with little or no information offered on ultimate ownership ndash should be of serious concern to UK Government Ministers.Unfortunately, thatrsquos not likely to be the case as far as the UK Government is concerned. A volley of evidence has been sent their way, but met only with indference.The UK Government must take a firm stance on limited partnerships being used to fund corrupt activities and perpetuate human-rights abuses, and stop ignoring the scandal that is continuing to take place on their doorstep.Alison Thewliss is the SNP MP for Glasgow Central

title: lord-adonis-scottish-labour-should-lead-the-way-in-calling-for-a-brexit-vote
story: Now, though, we are in the fight of our lives to stop this Brexit mess. The only way to solve the problems of the last referendum is via another vote - this time on the facts rather than on Nigel Farage and Boris Johnsonrsquos fantasies.I respect the leadership that Scotlandrsquos First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has shown in support of a Peoplersquos Vote to stop Brexit. In leaving aside questions about Scotlandrsquos relationship to the UK - for now - she has given us a chance of delivering for the Scottish people on the critical and urgent question of the UKrsquos relationship with our biggest and most important allies and trading partners. She has also shown that it is possible to rise above the partisan melee on Brexit. Scotland, England, Wales, Ireland - all will be poorer outside the EU, and the relationships between all four will also be impoverished.On Brexit, so far, my own Labour party has failed to provide the necessary leadership. We are stuck in a position of nothingness - waiting to see what Theresa May comes up with rather than articulating our own vision for a Scotland and a Britain that are proudly European. Labour votes and a Labour government were crucial for taking us into Europe in the s, and most Labour MPs and party members support a final say for voters on whatever May manages to negotiate . Our leaders now need to lead or young people in particular will turn away in disgust, outraged that their voices are being ignored, astonished that , people marching on Parliament have not been heeded.Over the last three days I have been with young people in Aberdeen, Perth, Edinburgh and Glasgow. Their message is a stark warning to Labour. Listen to us or face the consequences at the ballot box.Across the UK, Labour is in danger of alienating our voters, supporters and members by looking like followers on Brexit rather than the leaders people expect us to be. Nowhere is that more true than here in Scotland. Polls show that two-thirds of Scottish voters want a Peoplersquos Vote. This includes virtually every group and every city and region of the nation. Among Labour supporters in Scotland backing for a peoplersquos vote rises to  percent.So here is what needs to happen. Labour needs to lead not follow. In Scotland, Labour, the SNP, the Lib Dems and the Greens should make common cause against Brexit. There is a historic opportunity for Scottish Labour to show that - far from being a lsquobranch officersquo - it can inspire the party across the UK and change UK-wide policy.Urgently, Scottish Labour should say to Jeremy Corbyn that a Peoplersquos Vote cannot be the least worst option in terms of party policy but must be the vow that Labour makes to voters. Nicola Sturgeonrsquos big, bold offer to trust voters in Scotland and beyond on Brexit is a wake up call to Scottish Labour. But it is also an opportunity. Scottish Labour now needs to step up and stand up for the voters - and the nation.Lord Adonis is a Labour peer

title: peer-snp-support-for-brexit-vote-is-wake-up-call-for-scottish-labour
story: Lord Adonis, a prominent supporter of a ldquopeoplersquos vote on the final Brexit deal, also called on Richard Leonardrsquos party to persuade UK Labour to back the policy.He added that such a show of leadership would demonstrate that Scottish Labour is not a ldquobranch office - a jibe coined by former party chief Johann Lamont.Although the UK voted to leave the European Union, over % of voters north of the border backed staying in the EU.Three political parties in Scotland - the Liberal Democrats, Greens and the SNP - support another referendum, but Scottish Labour is lukewarm.UK party leader Jeremy Corbyn is sceptical about another vote and Mr Leonard is said to be reluctant to carve out a distinctive Scottish position.Lord Adonis, who served as a Minister in the Blair and Brown Governments, has been in Scotland to talk about what he regards as the merits of a final vote.In an article for the Herald on Sunday, he wrote that his own party had ldquofailed to provide the necessary leadership on Brexit and is stuck in a ldquoposition of nothingness.He argued: ldquoAcross the UK, Labour is in danger of alienating our voters, supporters and members by looking like followers on Brexit rather than the leaders people expect us to be. Nowhere is that more true than here in Scotland.He urged Scottish Labour to make ldquocommon cause against Brexit alongside the SNP, Lib Dems and the Greens:ldquoThere is a historic opportunity for Scottish Labour to show that - far from being a lsquobranch officersquo - it can inspire the party across the UK and change UK-wide policy.The peer added: ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos big, bold offer to trust voters in Scotland and beyond on Brexit is a wake up call to Scottish Labour. But it is also an opportunity. Scottish Labour now needs to step up and stand up for the voters - and the nation.Peter Grant MP, SNP spokesperson on Exiting the EU, said: ldquoThe Labour Party are still in total disarray when it comes to their policy on Brexit. Itrsquos no wonder that they cannot be taken seriously as a credible opposition to the Tories when their wake up calls come from unelected politicians from their own party in the House of Lords.Scottish Liberal Democrat Brexit spokesperson Tavish Scott said:"We know a sizeable majority of Labour supporters in Scotland dont agree with the partys pro-Brexit policy. Polls show they back a vote on the deal and want to stay in the EU."Kezia Dugdale and Ian Murray back a vote on the deal. Are there no other Scottish Labour politicians willing to do the right thing and join the Liberal Democrats in campaigning for people to have the final say, and the opportunity to Exit from Brexit "A Scottish Labour spokesperson said: ldquoAs Lord Adonis should be aware, Labour conference passed a motion which keeps the option of a Peoplersquos Vote on the table. If MPs canrsquot agree on whatever deal the Prime Minister comes back with, then we must have an immediate general election. If there isnrsquot a General Election, our position is that all options should remain on the table, including campaigning for a public vote.

title: concrete-actions-needed-to-end-austerity-finance-secretary-says
story: Theresa May told the Conservative party conference earlier this month that austerity is over and ldquopeople need to knowhellipthat their hard work has paid off.Derek Mackay has called for a ldquomeaningful uplt in public services funding in Mondayrsquos Budget.The Finance Secretary has already written to Philip Hammond toasked for the rollout of Universal Credit to be postponed until issues are addressed.Mr Mackay said: ldquoThe Prime Minister recently announced she would bring an end to austerity and I want to see this delivered within the UK Governmentrsquos Budget.ldquoThis statement must be backed up by concrete actions to provide a meaningful uplt in funding for public services, in addition to the funding increases announced for the NHS being delivered as a true net benefit and not offset by other cuts to the Scottish budget.He added: ldquoI urge the Chancellor to ensure he produces a Budget that ends austerity, boosts the economy and properly invests in public services in Scotland.ldquoThis Budget also comes as the prospect of a no-deal Brexit looms ever larger ndash something which poses the biggest threat to the UK economy and public finances.ldquoThat is why the UK Government should commit to continued membership of the single market and customs union,staying in the EU is not possible, which is around eight times larger than the UK market alone.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard has called on the Chancellor to change the rules onUniversal Credit and Child Tax Credits.In a letter to Mr Hammond he wrote: ldquoIt has been widely reported that the forthcoming Budget will finally end the age of austerity that Britain has lived under for eight years now. If that is the case, the Budget must end the two-child cap on tax credits.ldquoNo single policy sums up the immorality of the age of austerity better than the two-child cap. To punish families by limiting how much support they can get by their number of children is simply wrong.ldquoIn its first year, this policy has impacted on , households in Scotland, and the numbers of the families affected will only grow.The Scottish Conservatives want the Scottish Government to spend ldquoevery penny of extra funding from the Budget to be spent onhealth and social care.MSP Miles Briggs said: ldquoWe need to see more of our funding going to support GPs on the front line.ldquoWe need to see improvements to cancer treatment and it is time to cut the waste and inefficiency that is stopping doctors and nurses from getting on with their jobs.ldquoThe NHS in Scotland has a bright future. The SNP has run out of excuses. Letrsquos see Nicola Sturgeon set out a plan not a grievance for once.

title: scottish-air-passenger-duty-changes-could-reduce-public-service-funding
story: The Scottish Government had aimed to replace Air Passenger Dutywith an Air Departure Tax , set at half the current rate.However, it said plans to continue exempting journeys from airports in the Highlands and Islands required EU approval under state aid rules.Control over aviation tax was handed to the Scottish Parliament as part of the latest phase of devolution.Figures provided by the Scottish Parliament Information Centreindicate APD is expected to raise around pound. billion by  .However, projections suggested cutting the tax by at least % in the   Scottish Government budgetand retaining that level for the following five years until   would lead to forecast revenues being reduced to pound million.Finance Secretary Derek Mackay has already said implementing the new tax at the start of the next fiscal year in April  ldquois not possible.Despite that he said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has a longstanding commitment to reduce ADT by %.Scottish Labour said a reduction in the rate would deliver a tax cut for first class passengers and a lower investment in public services.James Kelly MSP, the partyrsquos finance spokesman, said: ldquoThese figures reveal just how much the SNP and Tory coalition to cut APD would harm Scotlandrsquos public services.ldquoRather than delivering a boon for first class passengers in cahoots with the Tories, the SNP should focus on using the powers of the Scottish Parliament to invest in Scotlandrsquos leline services.ldquoAhead of the budget, it is now the right time for SNP Finance Secretary Derek Mackay to announce he is dropping the unworkable and economically damaging plan to cut APD.A Scottish Government spokeman said: ldquoIt is simply wrong to say only first class passengers would benefit from any tax cut.ldquoOur plan to cut Air Departure Tax for passengers will improve Scotlandrsquos international connectivity, provide a boost to our economy, and a financial benefit to all types of households. This being especially important given the economic threat posed by Brexit.ldquoUK Air Passenger Duty is the most expensive tax of its kind in Europe and one of the highest in the world and continues to act as a barrier to Scotlandrsquos ability to secure new direct international services and maintain existing ones.lrmldquoWhile it continues to operate in Scotland, we call on the UK Government to act now and reduce APD rates to support connectivity and economic growth across the UK.

title: 30000-march-through-glasgow-calling-for-increase-in-teachers-pay
story: Scotlandrsquos largest teaching union, the EIS, organised the event, with general secretary Larry Flanagan hailing the turnout at the demo as ldquoabsolutely magnicent.Teachers, parents and their children and other campaigners marched from Glasgowrsquos Kelvingrove Park to George Square, where union leaders and politicians addressed crowds.So large was the rally that reports suggested when the first marchers arrived there, others were still waiting to set off.The EIS has been calling for teachers to be given a % rise to restore the value of salariesfollowing public sector pay caps.A pay offer which would have seen all teachers get a rise of % was rejected last month and was described as ldquoisive, with issues raised over the parity of pay.Education secretary John Swinney argued the deal would result in all teachers on the main grade scale receiving at least a % increase, with some teachers receiving up to % in one year in conjunction with annual progression.Message. Sent. Are you listening  @JohnSwinney @COSLA #ValueEducationValueTeachers #EISOct #PayAttention pic rvXemdash EISOctober , Speaking at the rally in George Square, Mr Flanagan said: ldquoIt is absolutely magnicent to look out on this massive demonstration and know that we are here, united, because we believe that the future of Scottish education is worth standing up and fighting for.ldquoOur pay claim is for % ndash given that the value of take-home pay has dropped by % in the last decade, that claim is already a compromise on what we deserve. And here is the simple fact ndashyou want to have qualied teachers in front of pupils in our schools, you need to address the recruitment and retention crisis we are facing.# Hour and a half between the front and back of the march arriving. Largest mobilisation by a single union in modern history.Amazing work @EISUnion! #ValueEducationValueTeachers #EISOct #PayAttention pic UTYvADfrmmdash Ross GreerOctober , EIS president Alison Thornton added: ldquoThe salaries of teachers in schools in Scotland are below the European average and those of other countries in the wider world.ldquoOur pupil contact hours are high, and we still work an average of  hours of unpaid overtime each week to deal with the demands of the job.ldquoAusterity doesnrsquot work, quality public services need proper funding and by investing in teachers then there is investment in education and our young people and their futures.Local government body Cosla said it took a joint decision with the Scottish Government to write to teachers ldquospelling out the value and merits of the pay offer currently on the table.The EIS will open a ballot of its members on Tuesday calling on them to reject the current offer. The ballot closes on November .Mr Swinney said: ldquoI hugely value the work teachers do and the vital contribution they make to improve outcomes for children.ldquoWe want teaching to be a rewarding career choice ndash to keep people in the profession and to attract new entrants ndash and that is why the Scottish Government is contributing an additional pound million this year for teachersrsquo pay.ldquoThrough a combination of a % increase for all staff earning up to pound,, restructuring the main grade scale and annual progression, the majority of teachers receive a rise between % and %. There would be a flat rate increase of pound, for those earning more than pound, from  April .The Education Secretary added thatreference to conditions of service forming part of the negotiations ldquois factually incorrect.He said: ldquoOur offer to teachers is for one year, and compares favourably with the pay award for the majority of health workers of % over three years and the recently announced award .% increase for police officers covering  months.ldquoI firmly believe this is a generous and fair offer which demonstrates the value both the Scottish Government and local government place on the teaching profession.ldquoWe remain committed to continuing discussions with teaching unions in good faith.But Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard, who addressed the rally, said it showed ldquoScotlandrsquos teachers wonrsquot be bullied into accepting another real terms pay cut by the SNP.He said: ldquoItrsquos time for Mr Swinney toput a fair pay deal on the table to provide teachers with therespect and due recognition they deserve.Meanwhile Scottish Green education spokesman Ross Greer hailed the demonstration as being the ldquolargest single-union march in modern history.He added: ldquoScotlandrsquos teachers have shown that they are ready to fight to win back some of the % their pay value has lost over the last decade.ldquoJohn Swinney should stop the threats to undermine unions, ditch his deeply unwanted governance reforms and address the real issues in our schools, namely a much-reduced, demoralised and overwhelmed teaching and support workforce trying to deliver the impossible with not nearly enough resources.

title: working-for-pennies-a-minute-the-merciless-reality-of-employment-in-modern-scotland
story: The details have emerged as part of a wider investigation into the gig economy, and precarious and insecure employment in Scotland.Other findings include:bull At least  per cent of the total Scottish workforce ndash some , people ndash deemed to be in insecure employment.bull Concerns that some social enterprises ndash firms meant to provide a social good and often in receipt of support from the taxpayer ndash are engaged in questionable employment practices.bull The rise of "bogus self-employment" where firms bring staff onboard, including waitresses and baristas, under self-employed terms ndash thereby not paying tax, national insurance, holiday pay, sick pay, or pension contributions ndash but treat them on the same terms asthey were staffbull Evidence of cash-in-hand payments used routinely in the gig economy, raising questions about losses to the exchequer.Trade union activists have described some of the worst examples of precarious employment as "Dickensian", "Victorian" and a throwback to the relationship between factory owners and workers in the th century. They also called on the Scottish government to tackle the problem with action, not words.The "paid by the minute" scandal centres on the care industry where councils outsource care at home to private or charitable companies. Care staff are electronically monitored ndash clocking in and out of a clientrsquos home ndash using technology such as mobile phones or iPads.As an example,a carer has five jobs in an hour each lasting six minutes then they will be paid by the minute for a total of  minutes. If the worker is on the Scottish living wage ndash pound. an hour ndash this would see them earn approximately pound. for an hourrsquos work, or just under  pence per minute. Many are not paid for the time in between jobs, or for travel to and from jobs.Scottish Care, which represents private care providers, estimates that the practice of "paying by the minute" occurs in half of Scotlandrsquos  council areas. An estimated  per cent ndash or  people ndash of the private care workforce, which stands at ,, are on zero-hours contracts, where most of the "paid by the minute" work is found. However, the numbers on ZHCs rises to - per cent in the sector of "older peoplersquos care".Care providers and carers are also penalisedworkers stay over the allotted time per visit, in the event of a client being ill or distressed.Scottish Care said: ldquoOver the last few years Scottish Care has continually argued for improvements to conditions which make employment in the care sector precarious for too many iniduals. One of these is the call to offer properly funded contracts to providers to enable them to reduce dependency on zero-hour contracts ... While admittedly some staff desire the flexibility that such contracts provide them with, from our research the vast majority of providers wish to move to a situation where adequate funding makes full-time contracts for the care workforce a possibility.ldquoThe main reason for the existence of zero-hours contracts is the discriminatory practice around the way in which care is bought from charitable and private providers by the public authorities. A local authority only pays for the work which is done rather than what may be intended. This makes it impossible to guarantee hours for many, especially smaller care providers."Scottish Care believes that we need to radically change the way we commission and buy care services ... At the moment many, especially smaller organisations, are effectively paid by the minute and therefore by extension unless the provider has its own reserves and assets the worker is paid by the minute. This is no way to deliver care in the st century.ldquoWe are faced with a scenario where workers are pressurised to get tasks done in as quick a time as possible and are penalisedthey are late for their next client. For the person receiving the care this makes the whole experience less than dignied despite the best efforts of inidual care workers ... This is especially unacceptable when we are talking about supporting people with palliative and end-of-le care.Dr Donald Macaskill, chief executive of Scottish Care, said: "There is something very wrong about a local authority treating its own staff fairly and well and yet treating the staff of services they buy in, whether they are employed by a charity or private care provider, in a manner which is little less than exploitative. Workers are made to clock in and clock out and their organisations are only being paid by the minute, and even thena worker is late or stays longer because someone needs more help or is ill they are being penalised.ldquoThese electronic call monitoring systems are treating care staff asthey cannot be trusted. They do not give dignity or value to a critical workforce. If we ever want to create a fair system of work we need a fair system for commissioning care."We have a massive challenge to attract people to do the fundamentally important job of care. People are being put off because of unfair conditions imposed by local authorities upon care organisations. How can we expect human-rights-based care in Scotland when we have created a system which denies the basic rights to the care worker and their employer "Jim McCourt, one of Scotlandrsquos most prominent trade unionists who runs the Inverclyde Advice and Employment Rights Centre in Greenock, brought the issue of care workers being paid by the minute to the attention of The Herald on Sunday."Itrsquos the ultimate in the gig economy," says McCourt. He blamed the issue on care providers bidding against each other for council contracts and creating ldquoa race to the bottom in the market. ldquoThey bid with prices they canrsquot meet and it is their workers who suffer," he said."These private care companies are funded by the public purse as they are contracted by councils ndash so our tax pounds are propping up this system," said McCourt, adding: "This is about looking after the most vulnerable people in society. We are looking at a value set here ndashpeople think there is money to be made in this way out of caring for the sick and elderly then there is something very wrong, especiallythe public purse is being used."One of Scotlandrsquos most senior care officials, who wished to speak anonymously, described the practice as "hypocritical and obscene"."To impose penalties because a care worker has stayed longer than was thought necessary with a client who is distressed or unwell is the very antithesis of what the care profession is about. We donrsquot treat nurses like. This is the worst type of precarious employment. The current system needs to end.A spokesperson for Cosla, the Scottish council umbrella organisation, said: ldquoCouncils work closely with the providers in their area to deliver and commission social care services. Inidual employers are responsible for their own practices but Cosla is trying to create an environment in which social care can be seen as an increasingly attractive career."This requires social care workers to be rewarded fairly and valued by their employers as well as by the rest of society.A spokesperson for the Care Inspectorate, which regulates care in Scotland, said: ldquoThe Care Inspectorate works closely with care providers to ensure that care in Scotland is as good as it can be. We expect everyone who relies on care at home to experience good-quality care which meets their needs and respects their rights and choices. Where care needs to improve we can, and do, use a wide range of powers to ensure this happens.ldquoWe also expect all care providers to adhere to all relevant professional guidance and standards. Anyone with a concern about a care service can contact us, anonymouslynecessary, on   .

title: tales-from-the-gig-economy-real-people-real-stories
story: ALANrsquoS experience of le in the gig economy nearly broke him. The control, the powerlessness ndash it all piled up and left him on the edge of a nervous breakdown, he says.Alan worked across Scotland for DPD ndash probably the best known courier service in the UK, sending packages around the country on behalf of retail giants like John Lewis and Marks and Spencer. Alan worked for the company ndash the biggest parcel provider after the Post Office ndash from .He saw an advert for an ldquoowner driver franchise with the company, billed as self-employment, and thought it would be a perfect fit for him. As self-employed Alan could work when he wanted, have weekends with his family, and be his own boss. Today, Alan describes the job as a ldquomassive lie.What Alan experienced is something campaigners call bogus self-employment ndash a growing phenomenon in the UK where employers bring someone on as self-employed but treat them asthey were a member of staff. That means they get none of the perks of being staff ndash they have to pay their own tax and national insurance, and they donrsquot get sick pay or holiday pay ndash but all of the drawbacks. ldquoWhen the bosses said jump, we had to say lsquohow high rsquo,Alan said.Alan got only two weeks holiday a year, had to work every Monday to Friday, as well as weekends when ordered, and when he worked there drivers were fined poundthey took a day off sick. Ruth Lane, the widow of DPD driver Don Lane, is suing the company over her husbandrsquos death. Lane missed medical appointments as he feared the pound fine. He had diabetes and had been charged by DPD after attending a specialist renal appointment. He went on to miss other appointments. He collapsed twice at work.His we says Lane was vomiting blood but still went to work due to his fear of being fined. On the day of his death, he completed his deliveries but suffered a heart attack when he arrived home and later died in hospital. In February, one month after Lanersquos death, DPD began to phase out fines and abolished them altogether in July. Alan says: ldquoIt is a disgrace that it took the death of a decent man to bring this about. It was a Victorian system.Alan also had to hire the van he drove from the company for nearly pound a month and pay for fuel and repairs. UK Government rules permit a maximum of  hoursrsquo driving in any working day ndash but Alan says he often spent  hours behind the wheel.Like all workers in the gig economy, it was the precarious nature of his employment which left Alan most vulnerable. ldquoWe were afraid to say anything. The threat was that you could be dismissed at any moment and told your services were no longer required so we did what we were told ndash we all have mortgages and mouths to feed, he said.Fair employment campaigners, like the Better Than Zero campaign run by the STUC in Scotland, believe many corporations can only generate the profits they do thanks to their employment practices ndash which often involve no contributions to sick pay, pensions, holidays, tax and national insurance. DPDrsquos operating profit rose  per cent last year to pound million.Alan said that, eventually, he ldquowas frightened of what was going to happen to myself and my health. I couldnrsquot carry on there because of the hours. I donrsquot like to admit it but I was honestly heading for a breakdown. I was bordering on tearful. I couldnrsquot even go to the doctor to get help as Irsquod get hit with a pound fine.He left his role as an ldquoowner driver franchisee with DPD earlier this year.lsquoManagement have the power ... staff have very few rightsrsquoWhen most people think of the gig economy, they think of a Deliveroo cyclist or an Uber driver ndash people working here and there were they can, earning a living in the new digitally-driven industries. But that view isnrsquot the whole picture.Fay waitresses at Grand Central Hotel in Glasgow and is on a zero-hours contract ndash a contract which guarantees you no working hours. For staff in all sectors, shts are often changed at the last moment and staff are sent home earlywork is quiet ndash and not paid for the hours they were due to work ndash and they are often asked and expected to work overtime at short notice.ldquoIt makes it exceptionally hard to manage your le, says Faye. Staff on these contracts in all employment sectors can see their pay fluctuate wildly depending on how much work they are offered, meaning it is hard to balance domestic finances. Childcare can become problematicstaff are asked to work at short notice, and late-night travel home worries many women staff.Faye, who is a union activist, said: ldquoZero-hours contracts give management the power to bully and harass ndash as staff just have to take it. Management give the hours to the people they think most deserve it. They have the power to do what they want and staff have very little rightsany.The owner regularly lsquoslaps female staff on the backsidersquoEmma, who waitresses at a well-known restaurant in Glasgow, spoke of the climate of sexism that pervades the hospitality industry for low-paid staff. Young women are often told to wear heels, skirts and make-up, and find thatthey donrsquot comply they can soon see their shts vanish.In the restaurant where she works the owner regularly ldquoslaps female staff on the backside. She added: ldquoMost are migrant workers with little English and they just take it as they feel it would be too hard to get another job.Emma also told of shts being cancelled at the last minute. In the restaurant where she works the biggest problem is that staff have no contracts at all. There was also delayed payment of wages to staff, short-changing for overtime, and staff being forced into split shtsthe restaurant was quiet ndash this would see a waitress told to take an unpaid break of two or three hours between lunch and dinner. ldquoIt seems like the employment policy is just to treat people like s**t, she said.Bad employment practices can also be reflected in a bad attitude to customers. Emma told of cheap brand vodka being decanted as Smirnoff at the restaurant, and wine from unfinished bottles being resold. ldquoI would love to report them to Trading Standards, she says, ldquobut how many people, including myself, will end up being out of work.lsquoI was sick but did a -hour sht as I was scared Irsquod get no workrsquoSandra also worked in a well known Glasgow restaurant ndash she, too, was given no contract. ldquoWithin a few weeks, I realised Irsquod got myself into a bad situation, she says. Her hours fluctuated hugely ndash sometimes she worked  hours a week, sometimes . Like many other waitresses, she found herself ordered homethe restaurant was quiet. After multiple staff departures, she found herself working  hour days.She was one of the few members of staff to receive pay slips. Sandra pestered the owners for correct paperwork as she wanted to ensure her tax and national insurance were being paid. Most other staff made no such demands. Suppliers were also paid cash in hand.ldquoOne week we were all paid cash in hand and told that tax was still being paid for us ndash but how did we know that was true  Sandra said. ldquoMost of my pay slips also had the wrong tax and national insurance information. Other staff who got pay slips found no tax had been taken off them even though they were earning over the threshold. I have no idea what on earth was going on when it came to the taxman.There were rodents in the food store ndash even though the venue has a prestigious reputation among diners. Staff were too scared to speak up about the problems all around them. ldquoThere were cases were people stood up to the bosses and they just didnrsquot get another sht. There were days when I was sick but came in and did a -hour sht as I was scared I would get no more work. Basically, the bosses were like greedy factory owners from the th century ndash they couldnrsquot get enough money and they didnrsquot care about staff.Sandra also spoke of bullying. On one occasion, staff had brought in their own food as they were working at a wedding reception all day. They left their lunches in bags in the staff room. A director tied the bags together and took bets on how long it would take hungry staff to get their food. ldquoThe impression you got is that we were not human in their eyes, says Sandra.Another member of staff describes her time at the restaurant as a ldquonightmare. She had no contract, her pay was late and she was given no payslip.ldquoThroughout my time there [the owners] consistently treated us like slaves, talked to us as though we were children and obviously considered us lesser human beings who didnrsquot deserve to be paid for the hard work we put in to keeping their business afloat.lsquoI have no idea how a waitress can be considered as self-employed, but I needed the workrsquoGwen Garret is  and now doing her masters degree in medieval history ndash but until recently she worked in one precarious job after another. ldquoThey were all terrible in their own way,rsquo she says. ldquoMost jobs were paying illegally with cash in hand. I would ask for pay slips and most refused.ldquoThere was a factory job ndash they paid with a pay slip. A cafe ndash that was cash in hand. A kebab place ndash that was cash in hand. A whisky bar ndash they paid with pay slips. A sushi place ndash they also refused to pay with a pay slip.Nerys, another masters student, also had a succession of precarious jobs ndash but her worst experience came when she worked for a social enterprise. Social enterprises are meant to help good causes ndash an example of a social enterprises doing what they are meant to do would be the Big Issue magazine which runs as a business but helps the homeless. Often, social enterprises get financial breaks and incentives from government.ldquoI have no idea how a waitress can be considered self-employed, but I needed the work, she said. ldquoThis was the most dodgy place I ever worked for. I also had all the down sides of a zero-hours contract ndash so I didnrsquot now how many hours I was getting or when I would get called on to work.Nerys said she worked for four months at the social enterprise and saw one person in all that time come to use the services for the disabled and elderly.The STUCrsquos Better Than Zero campaign is investigating this social enterprise and others.lsquoI ended up with anxiety ndash sitting in bed crying at nightrsquoBelinda was just  when she went to work as a waitress in a well-known Scottish restaurant. She experienced the usual zero-hours problems ndash random hours, unpaid overtime, tips not paid, split shts ndash and was also paid cash in hand. However, the schoolgirl was also touched inappropriately by a member of staff, and when she told her employer he said ldquojust stand up for yourself. No other action was taken.Kyle Scott also began working in hospitality aged just  and pulled pints in many bars around the Central Belt, where all of his employment was under a zero-hours contract. ldquoIt was always very dficult to get a day off as yoursquod be seen as a hindrance and the boss would just start cutting your shts. Irsquove seen people ask for a day off and just get told to get to f***, he said.He also spoke of sexual harassment of female staff by customers. ldquoYoung women would go to speak to the manager and be told lsquolook we need their revenue, they need to stay in the pubrsquo. So they arenrsquot kicked out. It happens widely across the hospitality industry.ldquoIf you are injured or sick or sexually harassed you say nothing as that could put you out of work ndash we basically have no rights. You drop everything do to what the boss says ndash asyou donrsquot, then you are scared you will never get a sht again.ldquoI ended up with an anxiety disorder ndash sitting in bed crying at night as I didnrsquot know what shts I was getting so I couldnrsquot plan my le. It was mentally and physically exhausting.Some weeks Kyle would work  hours, at other times he went without a sht for three weeks. ldquoYou have to suck up to the boss to get shts, and thatrsquos grim as you are put in direct competition with your peers and friends to see who gets the most shts.ldquoOne of my biggest memories is the number of people breaking down crying. Irsquod see that at least a few times a day as people were so mentally exhausted. We even had a joke that there was a lsquono crying in the glass washrsquo rule.Kyle is now working for Strathclyde student union after graduating and loves his new job in campaigns and policy. ldquoItrsquos a genuine breath of fresh air, he says, ldquoit is the first time I have ever been happy going to work. The contrast is from black to white.lsquoI want to make certain that other people donrsquot get stung like mersquoJosh Philliban had his taste of precarious employment in a pop-up food store ndash another sector heavily reliant on zero-hours contracts. He wasnrsquot paid a penny for a monthrsquos work, he says ndash and is still in dispute with his employer, who canrsquot be named for this reason.Josh says he worked nearly all of June and was owed almost pound. When he tried to get what he was owned, his employer hit him with allegations of theft, which Josh claims are lies. The row got uglier last week after the Herald on Sunday began trying to find out what had been going on.ldquoJosh said: lsquoI just want to make certain that other people donrsquot get stung like me.lsquoOur tax pounds are propping up this systemrsquoAmazon has courted more than a little controversy as an employer ndash and no-one knows more about what the giant gets up to than Jim McCourt, one of Scotlandrsquos most determined campaigners for employment rights, and the manager of Inverclyde Advice and Employment Rights Centre near Amazonrsquos Greenock plant.This is one of his busiest times of year as sub-contracted agency workers are drafted in to Amazon to work on the Christmas rush. ldquoThe worst and sharpest employment practices are bred in the sub-contract culture, McCourt says. ldquoThis is fundamental to how abuse and control takes place.Agency workers, says McCourt, are dismissed for the slightest infractions, such as too many toilet breaks orthey canrsquot make overtime. ldquoThey will get a phone call from the agency, McCourt says, ldquoand be told they are not required back. That terries the rest of the workforce.It also plunges people into poverty, says McCourt ndash as many agency workers were unemployed before entering the gig economy anddismissed will have to endure the wait for their benefits to be reinstated. Many have been sent by job centres to agencies and told to take the job the agencies offer them or risk being sanctioned.Amazon ndash which has around , UK workers and recognises no trade union ndash announced this month that it was raising wages for its staff employees. The move was hailed as a positive step forward by a company which has been under fire over employment practices for years. The Scottish Government had been criticised for giving Amazon pound.m in taxpayer money.Last month, though, new rules were announced that there would be no state handouts in Scotland for firms which did not pay the living wage. Shortly afterwards, Amazon announced it would raise wages for employees. What went pretty much unnoticed though was that Amazon simultaneously decided to phase out its bonus and stock award programmes for hourly workers.ldquoWhat that all amounts to, says McCourt, ldquois no benefit to the workers. Staff are furious but not surprised.In separate investigations, McCourt has also come across an increasing number of employers using absence management policies which seem designed to sack staff who have been off sick. ldquoThere is a growing occupational health industry which works hand-in-hand with employers to get staff dismissed, he said, citing cases where employers ignored details of sickness provided by GPs and consultants, but instead relied on assessments from private occupational health advisors which results in dismissal. ldquoThis is the world we live in, says McCourt.He has also uncovered a new scandal in the gig economy ndash workers being paid literally by the minute in the private care sector.As the care sector becomes increasingly privatised, companies are being hired by councils to provide care to the sick and elderly in their homes. Many care staff are on zero-hours contracts ndash but thousands are also paid by the minute.ldquoItrsquos the ultimate in the gig economy, says McCourt. ldquoCompanies bid against each other for a contract and it is a race to the bottom. They bid with prices they canrsquot meet and it is their workers who suffer.An example of a care worker paid by the minute would be as follows: a care worker has five jobs in an hour ndash going to the homes of clients to help with their personal needs and medication ndash each job takes six minutes, meaning the carer is viewed as having worked  minutes in an hour.ldquoThese private care companies are funded by the public purse, says McCourt, ldquoas they are contracted by councils ndash so our tax pounds are propping up this system. There is a big dference here to other employment practices as we are not talking about stacking CDs in a warehouse ndash this is about looking after the most vulnerable people in society.ldquoWe are looking at a value set here ndashpeople think there is money to be made in this way out of caring for the sick and elderly then there is something very wrong, especiallythe public purse is being used.Background: Workers are stepping back in time to darker ageA BROWSE through the files of Better Than Zero is like stepping into a time machine and travelling back to the days of the dark satanic mills of the Industrial Revolution.Itrsquos a litany of employees begging their boss for work, staff having to pander to management in order to secure shts, of bullying, harassment, humiliation, low wages, people living hand to mouth, and the steady erosion of pride and dignity. There are examples of female staff who have asked to change shts being texted by their male manager saying: "My we is out tonight, why donrsquot you come round and then I will change your sht.""The work is sold to the employee as flexible," says Sarah Collins of BTZ, "but there is no flexibility for the worker." Staff are expected to take what shts are offered to them, regardless of how few or how many the hours are ndashthey cause a fuss and stand up for themselves itrsquos unlikely they will get any more work. "All the control is with the employer," Collins adds.One of the latest issues within precarious employment is the rise of questionable practices within a small minority of social enterprise firms ndash companies meant to be doing a social good and often in receipt of financial support from the public purse. Some social enterprises are hiring staff on zero hours contracts ldquothen quickly sacking or dismissing themthey raise any concerns. BTZ spoke of firms claiming to be involved in sustainable transport initiatives pressurising and bullying staff on zero hour contracts, or paying cash in hand. There are reports of similar behaviour by social enterprise companies refurbishing kitchen goods or furniture for the poor and elderly to buy at cheap rates."On the surface they look great, and there are plenty of social enterprises doing great work but the model has been perverted by a few for bad reasons," BTZ said."Bogus self-employment" is another new problem ndash it crossed over from the gig economy where some food delivery drivers were hired on a self-employed basis and is now in many sectors. The organisation cites the case of a beautician in a nail bar who was taken on as self-employed but was told by management when to come in, when to go home, and how much to charge."They are not self-employed at all," says BTZ. "It is just a cost saving exercise as the employer is not paying tax, national insurance, sick pay, holiday pay, or pension contributions. There is a big issue here of the exchequer potentially missing out on huge amounts of tax.Self-employment has massively increased since the financial crash of . The largest increase is among women in the following three occupations: cleaners, child minders and hairdressers. Most people drt in and out of self-employment as they look for more stable, less precarious jobs."The Scottish Government is projecting Scotland as a wonderful place to visit, but who is checking on the labour conditions of the people in the tourism industry," BTZ says.At the core of the problems with zero hours contracts, in particular, is the bullying it seems to enable in the worst managers ndash staff who want to work as many hours as possible are unlikely to defend themselvestreated badly by their boss. Precarious employment also affects young workers in their late teens and early s more than other age groups."Bullying is everywhere," says BTZ. "This leads to burn out, mental health problems...unemployment may be at an all time low but the human cost is Dickensian. Couple all this with the housing situation and you see that precarious work leads to precarious lives. If you donrsquot have a steady income and are just bumping from job to job and house to house, every aspect of your le is affected."If you are on zero hours you arenrsquot going to get a mortgage, and yoursquoll need a guarantor for private rented accommodation. Thatrsquos why sofa surfacing is on the rise, why people who previously lived independently are moving back home to their parents. It makes people vulnerable not just to loan sharking but even sex for rent. It all knits together. This is what young people have come to expect in Scotland in .Insecure work can also mean in-work poverty as well. Two parents in insecure employment can actually be worse off financially than a family on benefits.Precarious employment has a corrosive effect, with zero hour contracts now even affecting university lecturers it is little wonder, BTZ believes, that young people are leaving school with a jaded view of the world of work and the opportunities on offer to them."The most depressing thing is that young people think this is the norm," said Sarah Collins. "They know what is happening is not right, but they donrsquot have any expectation of any other type of work."Better Than Zero said: "It is all well and good saying we want a fair work society, a fair work economy, but on the frontline it is almost laughable how far these claims and aspirations are from the way that huge numbers of people make a living."BTZ said that the impact on mental health of precarious employment was a growing problem. Disabled workers are often the most vulnerable to exploitation too. If a disabled worker on a zero hours contract starts asking for wheelchair ramps, or other assistance at work, itrsquos easy for an unscrupulous employer to just take them off the rota, BTZ says.The night-time economy, where a lot of precarious employment is found, is only set to grow in Scotland as bars and clubs push for later licensing laws. Butyou are a young female member of staff on zero hours, with little power to argue for an earlier sht, then going home late at night becomes a hazard of work. Few companies pay for staff to get taxis even in the early hours of the morning.BTZ has accounts in its files of staff finishing work at am and waiting for the first bus in the morning to get home, or staff going to a casino that stays open until dawn and buying one drink to nurse until public transport starts again. There are reports of female staff being harassed and intimidated on late night streets.As the campaign team of BTZ say of all the cases they are investigating, "is a little dignity, respect, and safety too much to ask "The Herald on Sunday asked the Scottish Government to put forward the relevant minister for interview on matters related to precarious employment and the gig economy. No interview was forthcoming.Reaction: what the companies sayGRAND CENTRAL HOTELA spokesperson for Grand Central said they did not accept that the comments about the hotel ldquoin any way represent the experience of our valued colleagues. As seen across the wider hospitality industry, the hotel employs an appropriate level of permanent employees, on full and partndashtime contracts, supplemented by flexible team members as customer demand fluctuates across the year.ldquoAt all times, we treat colleagues with dignity and respect which is reflected in our high staff approval ratings.AMAZONAn Amazon spokesperson said the company ldquodidnrsquot recognise the allegations as an accurate portrayal of activities in our buildings.It added: ldquoAmazon provides a safe and positive workplace for thousands of people across the UK with competitive pay and benefits from day one. We have a focus on ensuring we provide a great environment for all our employees and Amazon was recently named by LinkedIn as the seventh most sought after place to work in the UK and ranked first place in the US. Amazon also offers public tours of its fulfilment centres so customers can see first-hand what happens after they click buy on Amazon by visiting uk.amazonfctours.ldquoAs we are growing and constantly hiring more associates, it is strongly in our interests to retain people and no one is ever dismissed without good reason. We completely support associates working for us and people are allowed to use the toilet whenever needed. We also have an exception process so that associates can alert us to times when they just cannot do overtime for valid personal reasons."We respect the inidual rights of associates to join a trade union. We have an open-door policy that encourages associates to bring their comments, questions, suggestions or concerns directly to their management team.
